title: BB&T v. Carolina Crank & Core
description: Bruce Tipi appeals the circuit court's grant of Branch Banking and Trust Company of South Carolina's motion for summary judgment, which rendered him personally liable on a $325,000 guaranty owed to the Bank.  Tipi alleges the circuit court erred in finding the guaranty was supported by sufficient legal consideration and mutual assent.  We affirm finding sufficient consideration and mutual assent in the simultaneous execution of the bank's agreement to extend a line of credit and Tipi's guaranty.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Branch Banking and Trust Company of South Carolina,
Respondent,
v.
Carolina Crank & Core, Inc., Michael D.
McNelis, Kenneth F. Taylor, 
        Robert Thompson and Bruce Tipi, Defendants,
Of Whom Bruce Tipi is Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Spartanburg County
Â Larry R. Patterson, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 3942
Submitted January 1, 2005 â€“ Filed February 
  7, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
F. Milton Mann, Jr., of Spartanburg, for Appellant.
Seann A. Gray, of Greenville, for Respondent.
      
    
  

HEARN, C.J.:Â  In this civil action, Bruce Tipi appeals the 
  circuit courtâ€™s grant of Branch Banking and Trust Company of South Carolinaâ€™s 
  motion for summary judgment.Â  As a result, Tipi was found to be personally liable 
  on a $325,000 guaranty owed to the Bank.Â  We affirm. [1] 
FACTS
In December 1998, Michael McNelis, Kenneth Taylor, 
  and Robert Thompson purchased an automotive crankshaft division of a company 
  and incorporated as Carolina Crank & Core, Inc.Â  McNelis, Taylor, and Thompson 
  obtained a term loan from Branch Banking and Trust Company of South Carolina [2]  (â€œBankâ€), to assist in the purchase.Â  
  The Bank also agreed to extend a line of credit in the amount of $175,000, as 
  evidenced by the companyâ€™s promissory note dated February 2, 1999, with a maturity 
  date of February 2, 2000.Â  In addition to other security given by the company 
  to the Bank, McNelis, Taylor, and Thompson executed and delivered their personal 
  guaranty to the bank thereby securing payment of the indebtedness owed to the 
  bank.Â  This line of credit is the indebtedness at issue.
In May 1999, the Bank increased the line of credit to $225,000, 
  as evidenced by the Companyâ€™s promissory note dated May 10, 1999, with the original 
  maturity date of February 2, 2000.Â  Again the personal guaranties of McNelis, 
  Taylor, and Thompson were executed and delivered to the Bank, securing the indebtedness 
  owed to the Bank.Â  The Bank subsequently extended a second line of credit, distinct 
  from the original line of credit, in the amount of $100,000.Â  The Company executed 
  and delivered its promissory note to the Bank on November 24, 1999, also reflecting 
  the same February 2, 2000 maturity date as the original line of credit.Â  Again 
  the personal guaranties of McNelis, Taylor, and Thompson were executed and delivered 
  to the Bank.Â  
Both lines of credit matured on February 2, 2000, 
  and at that time the Bank agreed to renew the lines of credit for an additional 
  three months.Â  Moreover, the Bank combined the two lines of credit into a single 
  line with a total indebtedness of $325,000.Â  The Company executed and delivered 
  its promissory note to the Bank on February 2, 2000, evidencing this consolidation, 
  and also reflecting the new May 2, 2000 maturity date.Â  Once again the personal 
  guaranties of McNelis, Taylor, and Thompson were executed and delivered to the 
  Bank, securing the indebtedness.Â  
As of the August 2, 2000 maturity date, the Bank had made 
  a decision not to renew the outstanding line of credit due to the poor financial 
  condition of the Company.Â  J. Timothy Camp, the Bank loan executive responsible 
  for the Companyâ€™s line of credit, informed McNelis, in his capacity as company 
  president, that the Bank would be unwilling to renew the line of credit without 
  the Company obtaining additional Bank-approved security, including a new guarantor.Â  

McNelis informed Camp the company was in the process of acquiring 
  an additional investor.Â  McNelis identified Bruce Tipi, the appellant, as the 
  potential investor.Â  Tipi decided to become an investor, shareholder, and employee 
  of the Company in an agreement formalized on September 25, 2000.Â  
Camp testified the Bank required Tipiâ€™s personal guaranty as a condition 
  of renewing the line of credit, and no renewal would have been approved absent 
  Tipiâ€™s guaranty.Â  The Credit Approval Report narrative prepared by Camp on October 
  4, 2000 illustrated the Bankâ€™s position.Â  The CAR report stated: â€œThe [Company] 
  has requested that [Bank] renew an existing $325K line of credit . . . [Bank] 
  will require the personal guarantee of Mr. Bruce W. Tipi.â€Â  On October 6, 2000, 
  Camp prepared the appropriate documentation to renew the line of credit, which 
  included a new promissory note, effective date August 2, 2000, and a guaranty, 
  also effective date of August 2, 2000.Â  The guaranty had four signature lines, 
  under which the names of McNelis, Taylor, Thompson, and Tipi were typed.Â  Upon 
  receipt of the signed documents, including the fully executed guaranty complete 
  with the signature of Tipi, the Bank renewed the line of credit effective retroactively 
  to August 2, 2000 with a maturity date of April 2, 2001.Â  
Ultimately, the Company defaulted on its obligation to the Bank.Â  
  The Bank commenced this action seeking to collect on the outstanding indebtedness 
  under the promissory note and under the signed guaranty.Â  Tipi denied liability 
  under the signed guaranty, asserting a failure of consideration. [3] Â  The circuit court rejected Tipiâ€™s 
  argument and granted summary judgment in favor of the Bank, thus rendering Tipi 
  liable under the guaranty.Â  Tipi appeals the grant of summary judgment.  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
Summary judgment is appropriate â€œif the pleadings, depositions, 
  answers to interrogatories, and admissions on file, together with the affidavits, 
  if any, show that there is no genuine issue as to any material fact and that 
  the moving party is entitled to a judgment as a matter of law.â€Â  Rule 56(c), 
  SCRCP.Â  In determining whether any triable issues of fact exist, the court must 
  view the facts in the light most favorable to the non-moving party.Â  George 
  v. Fabri, 345 S.C. 440, 452, 548 S.E.2d 868, 874 (2001). 
â€œIn reviewing the grant of a summary judgment motion, this 
  court applies the same standard which governs the trial court: summary judgment 
  is proper when â€˜there is no genuine issue as to any material fact and that the 
  moving party is entitled to a judgment as a matter of law.â€™â€Â  Regions Bank 
  v. Schmauch, 354 S.C. 648, 659, 582 S.E.2d 432, 438 (Ct. App. 2003) (citations 
  omitted).Â Â Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
Tipi 
  advances two primary arguments in support of his position that the circuit court 
  erred in granting the Bankâ€™s motion for summary judgment.Â  First, Tipi alleges 
  the circuit court erred in finding the guaranty was supported by sufficient 
  legal consideration.Â  Second, Tipi claims the circuit court erred in finding 
  mutual assent existed between Tipi and the Bank.Â  We disagree as to both arguments 
  and affirm.

  
  
    
       I. 
       
  The circuit court correctly found the guaranty was supported by sufficient legal 
  consideration.
    
  
  

Tipi 
  argues the circuit court erred in finding the guaranty was supported by sufficient 
  legal consideration.Â  He alleges a lack of sufficient legal consideration because 
  the Bank did not advance any additional funds after receipt of the guaranty.Â  
  We disagree.
â€œA guaranty is â€˜a promise to answer for the payment of some debt 
  or the performance of some duty in case of the failure of another person who 
  is himself in the first instance, liable to such payment or performance.â€™â€Â  
  Crafton v. Brown, 346 S.C. 347, 350-51, 550 S.E.2d 904, 905 (Ct. App. 
  2001) (citation omitted).Â  A guaranty must be supported by sufficient legal 
  consideration, which can consist of either a benefit to the principal obligor 
  or guarantor, or some detriment to the obligee.Â  Hope Petty Motors of Columbia, 
  Inc. v. Hyatt, 310 S.C. 171, 178, 425 S.E.2d 786, 791 (Ct. App. 1992).Â  
  Consideration that is wholly past is not valuable consideration.Â  Future 
  Group, II v. Nationsbank, 324 S.C. 89, 97, 478 S.E.2d 45, 49 (1996 (citation 
  omitted)).Â  If all debt was pre-existing, the guaranty must â€œbe supported by 
  some new consideration other than the original debt.â€Â  Id.Â  Moreover, 
  the guarantor need not derive any benefit from either the principal contract 
  or the guaranty provided there is a benefit to the principle obligor or a detriment 
  to the creditor.Â  Crafton, 346 S.C. at 354, 550 S.E.2d at 907.
In this 
  case, in exchange for receiving Tipiâ€™s guaranty, the Bank agreed to extend the 
  line of credit for an additional eight months past the original maturity date, 
  thus forbearing on its pre-existing right to enforce other remedies, including 
  collection under the original note.Â  This agreement to extend the line of credit 
  and forebear exercising remedies available to the Bank was a benefit to the 
  Company and Tipi as shareholder, guarantor, and employee, as well as a detriment 
  to the Bank.Â  
Tipi 
  further asserts the circuit court erred in finding consideration was legally 
  sufficient because the guaranty was not executed simultaneously with the note.Â  
  We disagree.
If a 
  note and guaranty are executed simultaneously, the consideration of the note 
  functions as consideration for the guaranty; however, if the documents are not 
  executed simultaneously, there is no presumption of consideration, and the consideration 
  must be proved.Â  See id. at 351, 550 S.E.2d at 907.
In this 
  situation, the only evidence regarding the execution of the note and the guaranty 
  was testimony offered by Camp.Â  Camp testified he prepared the new line of credit 
  and guaranty documents together on October 6, 2000 and delivered them to the 
  Company for the requisite signatures.Â  Camp testified that the line of credit 
  would not have been renewed prior to the Bankâ€™s receipt of the signed guaranties.Â  
  Additionally, the executed loan renewal documents, including Tipiâ€™s signed personal 
  guaranty, were returned to the Bank and entered into the Bankâ€™s computer system 
  on October 12, 2000.Â  Tipi offered no evidence to the contrary at trial.Â  Therefore, 
  we find the circuit court correctly held the note was prepared and executed 
  simultaneous to the guaranty, that it was forwarded for signatures contemporaneous 
  with the guaranty, and that the Bank renewed the line of credit upon receipt 
  of all the signed documents.Â  Moreover, even if the note and guaranty were not 
  executed simultaneously, we have previously held the guaranty was supported 
  by the additional consideration of the Bank foregoing the remedies available 
  to it at the time of the guaranty.Â  Accordingly, we affirm the ruling of the 
  circuit court.

  
    
    
      
        II.
         The circuit court did not err in finding mutual assent existed between 
  Tipi and the Bank. 
   
      
    
    
  

Tipi 
  claims the circuit court erred in finding mutual assent existed between Tipi 
  and the Bank.Â  We disagree and affirm.
â€œA contract 
  of guaranty, like every other contract, can only be made by the mutual assent 
  of the parties.â€Â  Crafton, 346 S.C. at 354, 550 S.E.2d at 907.Â  â€œIf the 
  guaranty is signed by the guarantor at the request of the other party, or if 
  the latterâ€™s agreement is contemporaneous with the guaranty, the mutual assent 
  is proved, and the delivery of the guaranty to him or for his use completes 
  the contract.â€Â  Id.Â  
Because 
  the guaranty and promissory note were executed contemporaneously, further evidence 
  of a meeting of the minds is not necessary.Â  Therefore, the circuit court did 
  not err in finding that mutual assent existed between Tipi and the Bank, and 
  the grant of summary judgment is hereby
AFFIRMED. 
 GOOLSBY and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

 
   [1]  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant 
    to Rule 215, SCACR.

 
   [2]  The loan was initially with First Federal Bank, 
    which was purchased by Branch Banking and Trust Company of South Carolina 
    in 2001. 

 
   [3]  The parties agree Tipi, along with McNelis, Taylor, 
    and Thompson, executed the guaranty document.Â  The parties disagree only as 
    to whether this guaranty is enforceable against Tipi.

title: Arnal v. Arnal
description: Husband appeals from the order of the family court which granted the parties a divorce, divided the marital property, imputed income to Husband, established child support and visitation, and required him to pay attorneys' fees and guardian ad litem fees.  Wife also appeals, constesting the equitable distribution and the determination of marital property.  We affirm in part, reverse in part, and remand.
text:
Arnal v. Arnal


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Laura Lawton Arnal, Respondent/Appellant,
v.
David Emil Arnal, Appellant/Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Beaufort County
Â Robert S. Armstrong, Family Court Judge

Opinion No. 3943
Heard September 16, 2004 â€“ Filed February 
  7, 2005

AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART and REMANDED


  
    
      
Sally G. Calhoun, of 
  Beaufort, for Appellant-Respondent.
Susan C. Rosen, Robert N. Rosen and Donald B. Clark, all of Charleston, 
  for Respondent-Appellant.
      
    
  

HEARN, C.J.:Â Â Â Â  
  David Arnal (Husband) appeals from the final order of the family court which 
  granted the parties a divorce, divided the marital property, imputed income 
  to Husband, established child support and visitation, and required him to pay 
  attorneysâ€™ fees and guardian ad litem fees.Â Â  Laura Lawton Arnal (Wife) also 
  appeals, contesting the equitable distribution and the determination of marital 
  property.Â  We affirm in part, reverse in part, and remand.
FACTS
The parties were married 
  in 1995.Â  In 1999, they had a son who was diagnosed with Downâ€™s Syndrome.Â  Both 
  prior to and during the partiesâ€™ marriage, Husband was employed by Wifeâ€™s father 
  in his development company.Â  Wifeâ€™s father, Charles Fraser, was one of the main 
  developers of Hilton Head Island, where the parties resided.Â  The parties separated 
  in 1999, shortly after the child was born.Â  
Wife and child now reside 
  in Brevard, North Carolina in a home purchased by one of two trusts under which 
  she is a beneficiary.Â  Â Â Father remained in Hilton Head and started his 
  own consulting and land development business.Â  Wifeâ€™s main source of income 
  is from the family trusts.Â  She is also employed part time in order to be able 
  to devote time to the childâ€™s special needs. 
This case has a very 
  litigious history.Â  Wife initiated the action seeking custody of the child, 
  child support, division of the property, and ultimately a divorce.Â  Husband 
  answered, requesting joint legal custody, equitable division, and rehabilitative 
  or lump sum alimony.Â  
A temporary hearing was held in January 2000, in which the parties were granted 
  joint legal custody, with Wife having physical custody and decision-making authority 
  with regard to the childâ€™s treatment. That temporary order granted Husband visitation 
  in Brevard only and required him to pay $621.78 a month in child support.
In May 2000, Husband 
  moved for a change of custody as a result of Wifeâ€™s failure to begin therapies 
  for the child.Â  Additionally, Husband contended Wife had failed to complete 
  the childâ€™s vaccinations.Â  By the time of the hearing, Wife had commenced therapy 
  and completed the vaccinations, so the change in custody was denied. Â 
Husband 
  then moved to compel discovery and to amend his pleadings to seek custody of 
  the child.Â  In return to Husbandâ€™s motion, Wife sought the following relief: 
  psychological testing of the parties; sole custody; sanctions for Husbandâ€™s 
  failure to comply with Rule 11, SCRCP; and a restraining order against Husband.Â  
  The court compelled Wife to comply with discovery, declined sanctions against 
  Husband, dismissed the motion for a restraining order, and continued the issue 
  of custody of the child.Â  Wifeâ€™s request for psychological testing was abandoned.
In October 2000, the family court denied Wifeâ€™s request for sole custody 
  and granted Husband overnight visitation in the Brevard area and visitation 
  in Hilton Head once a month.Â  A second order required Husband to answer interrogatories 
  and produce requested documents.Â  
Thereafter, Wife filed a rule to show cause against Husband seeking 
  to compel him to pay his portion of the medical expenses for the child.Â  The 
  court found Husband in contempt and ordered him to pay the expenses and $1,000 
  in attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  Wife filed a subsequent rule to show cause in December 
  2000, after Husband failed to pay medical expenses and failed to respond to 
  discovery requests.Â  Husband had complied by the date of the hearing, so the 
  court did not hold him in contempt, though it reserved the issue of legal fees, 
  required Husband to pay the medical expenses, and ordered him to produce documents. 

In February 2001, upon Wifeâ€™s motion, the family court reviewed Husbandâ€™s 
  visitation. The court concluded that because the child â€œha[d] been suffering 
  illnesses since December and the final hearing in this matter [was] scheduled 
  shortly, and since it [was] the cold and flu seasonâ€ it would be in the childâ€™s 
  best interest for all visitation to occur in Brevard rather than having the 
  child travel to Hilton Head pending the final hearing.Â Â  Â Â 
Wife subsequently filed a motion to hold Husband in contempt for his 
  failure to respond to discovery and produce documents that he claimed contained 
  a confidentiality agreement involving investment property he owned with others.Â Â  
  The family court held Husband in contempt and ordered him to pay $10,000 in 
  legal fees to Wife.Â  The same order relieved Husbandâ€™s counsel and appointed 
  a new guardian ad litem for the child.Â  Husband did not appeal the contempt 
  order until the filing of the current appeal. Â 
This action was tried 
  in April 2001.Â Â Â  In its final order, the family court granted Wife sole custody 
  of the child and gave her the right to control all medical and educational decisions 
  for the child.Â  Â Â Husband received visitation on alternating weekends, 
  but the first and third visitation of the month were required to be in Brevard 
  rather than at Husbandâ€™s home in Hilton Head.Â Â  Additionally, the visitation 
  in Brevard was limited to no more than one hour travel, and Husband was required 
  to provide documentation to that effect.Â  The visitation restrictions were to 
  end when the minor reached forty-three months of age. 
  [1] Â  
The final order also 
  divided the marital property.Â  The court granted Husband the properties he acquired 
  through his partnership and split the personal possessions.Â  Additionally, in 
  calculating child support, the court imputed income to Husband in the amount 
  of $9,060.62 per month and imputed income to Wife in the amount of $5,012.40 
  per month.Â  According to their sworn financial declarations filed pursuant to 
  Rule 20, SCRFC, Husband earned $3,656 per month and Wife earned $4,750 per month. 
  Husband was required to pay $1,564 in child support and to pay his pro-rata 
  share (64%) of uncovered medical expenses.Â  The court required Wife to apply 
  for Medicaid and to research and apply for any other financial assistance available 
  in order to pay the costs of caring for the child.Â  
The family court ordered 
  the guardianâ€™s fee to be paid equally by the parties up to the date of trial 
  and required Husband to bear the full cost of the guardianâ€™s fee at trial.Â  
  The court found Husband should be responsible for the full fee at trial because 
  â€œthe issue of visitation was tried primarily because [Husband] would not accept 
  the Guardian ad Litemâ€™s recommendations.â€Â  Finally, after analyzing the appropriate 
  factors, the court ordered Husband to pay $65,000 in attorneysâ€™ fees in addition 
  to the $10,000 and $1,000 awards previously ordered.Â  
Husband filed a motion 
  for reconsideration, challenging many aspects of the family courtâ€™s order.Â  
  The motion was denied in October 2001.Â  
Subsequent to the final 
  order, Wife filed a rule to show cause seeking to hold Husband in contempt on 
  the grounds that: Husband failed to pay uncovered medical expenses, Husband 
  failed to pay his August child support in full, Husband failed to provide documentation 
  he was not traveling more than one hour from Brevard, and Husband failed to 
  pay the remaining balance of $500 on the previous attorneysâ€™ fees award of $1,000. 

The hearing was held 
  on November 6, 2001.Â  During the hearing, Wife presented the fee affidavit of 
  one of her two attorneys.Â  The attorney was not present, and Husband requested 
  the hearing be continued so that he could cross-examine the attorney on her 
  fee.Â  The subsequent hearing was held two days later.Â  
Following the second hearing, the family court issued two orders in 
  February 2002.Â  One found Husband should pay the increased child support as 
  of August 1, but did not find him in willful contempt for failing to do so.Â  
  Additionally, he was found in contempt for failing to make timely payments on 
  medical bills and thereafter required to pay uncovered medicals within fourteen 
  days from the date Wife mailed him notice.Â  Husband was found in contempt for 
  failing to pay the remaining balance on the $1,000 attorneysâ€™ fees and was ordered 
  jailed for ten days with the ability to purge the contempt by paying the $500 
  remaining.Â  
The second order required Husband to pay $4,727.25 in attorneysâ€™ fees 
  as a result of Wifeâ€™s institution of the rule to show cause.Â  This amount was 
  over $2,000 more than the amount submitted at the initial hearing on the rule 
  to show cause. 
Husband 
  has appealed the Amended Final Order, the order denying his motion for reconsideration, 
  and the orders resulting from the rule to show cause. 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In appeals 
  from the family court, this court may find facts in accordance with its own 
  view of the preponderance of the evidence. Rutherford v. Rutherford, 
  307 S.C. 199, 204, 414 S.E.2d 157, 160 (1992); Owens v. Owens, 320 S.C. 
  543, 546, 466 S.E.2d 373, 375 (Ct. App. 1996).Â  However, this broad scope of 
  review does not require us to disregard the family courtâ€™s findings.Â  Stevenson 
  v. Stevenson, 276 S.C. 475, 477, 279 S.E.2d 616, 617 (1981).Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS

  A.                          
HUSBANDâ€™S APPEAL 
   
  
    
    
      
        1.   
   
        Whether the family court erred in imputing income to Husband 
   
      
    
    
  

Husband asserts the family court erred 
  by imputing to him an additional $5,403.56 per month in income for calculation 
  of child support. [2] Â  We agree.
The South Carolina Child 
  Support Guidelines define â€œincomeâ€ as â€œthe actual gross income of the parent 
  if employed to full capacity, or potential income if unemployed or underemployed.â€Â  
  27 S.C. Code Ann. Regs. 114-4720(A) (Supp. 2003).Â  The guidelines further provide:

Potential Income.Â  If the court finds that a parent is voluntarily 
  unemployed or underemployed, it should calculate child support based on a determination 
  of potential income which would otherwise ordinarily be available to the parent.Â  


27 S.C. Code Ann. Regs. 114-4720(A)(5) (Supp. 
  2003).
During the marriage, 
  Husband was employed by Wifeâ€™s father.Â  Husbandâ€™s expert testified that his 
  annual income during this time was between $35,000 and $40,000, and Wife did 
  not contradict this testimony.Â  Following the separation, Husbandâ€™s employment 
  with Wifeâ€™s father was terminated, and he started his own consulting and land 
  development business.Â  Since beginning his own business, Husband made more money 
  than when working for his father-in-law.Â  According to his financial declaration, 
  Husband was earning nearly $44,000 at the time of trial.Â  Nevertheless, at Wifeâ€™s 
  urging, the family court imputed more income to Husband than he earned at any 
  time during the marriage.Â  
Wife argues that although 
  Husband has increased his income following the separation, he is not earning 
  income commensurate with his earning capacity, and that Husband is capable of 
  earning substantially more than his current income.Â  Wife points out that Husband 
  has an undergraduate degree from Clemson University and a masterâ€™s degree in 
  landscape architecture from Harvard University.Â  Wifeâ€™s position is that because 
  Husband is so well educated, he could earn more money than he is currently earning. 
  Wife essentially argues Husband is not billing his clients a high enough hourly 
  rate or billing the maximum number of hours.Â  
Even accepting Wifeâ€™s 
  assertions as true, we do not find this to be a case for imputation of income 
  because there is no indication that Husband has voluntarily lessened his earning 
  capacity.Â  â€œ[T]he failure to reach earning capacity, by itself, does not automatically 
  equate to voluntary underemployment such that income must be imputed.â€Â  Kelley 
  v. Kelley, 324 S.C. 481, 488-89, 477 S.E.2d 727, 731 (Ct. App. 1996).Â  â€œ[C]ourts 
  are to closely examine the payorâ€™s good-faith and reasonable explanation for 
  the decreased income.â€Â  Id. at 489, 477 S.E.2d at 731.Â  
In this case, there 
  is no evidence Husband has decreased his income at all.Â  In fact, his income 
  has increased since the time of the partiesâ€™ separation.Â  Moreover, the mere 
  fact that Husband could make additional income does not warrant the imputation 
  of income.Â  There is no evidence that Husbandâ€™s failure to make additional income 
  was due to any wrongdoing on his part or motivated by a desire to decrease his 
  support obligation.Â  See Mazzone v. Miles, 341 S.C. 203, 209, 
  532 S.E.2d 890, 893 (Ct. App. 2000) (declining to impute more than minimum wage 
  to husband when there was no evidence that the loss of his job was due to any 
  wrongdoing, or that his decision to start his own business was motivated by 
  a desire to avoid his child support obligations).Â  â€œ[C]ourts are reluctant to 
  invade a partyâ€™s freedom to pursue the employment path of their [sic] own choosing 
  or impose unreasonable demands on parties.â€Â  Kelley, 324 S.C. at 489, 
  477 S.E.2d at 731.Â  
The family court erred 
  in imputing income to Husband of over $9,000 per month because there is no evidence 
  in this record that Husband voluntarily depressed his income.Â  In fact, at the 
  time of the hearing, Husband was making more income in his new business 
  than he had ever earned during the partiesâ€™ marriage.Â  Following Wifeâ€™s argument 
  to its logical conclusion, a family court could impute income to a spouse if 
  it merely found that he or she was capable of earning more income.Â  This is 
  simply not the test for imputation of income in this state.Â  Therefore, because 
  we do not find Husband has voluntarily lessened his earning capacity, we reverse 
  the family courtâ€™s decision to impute income to him.Â  
However, for purposes 
  of setting child support we do not accept Husbandâ€™s income as stated on his 
  financial declaration.Â  Accordingly, we now undertake to establish Husbandâ€™s 
  income for purposes of determining child support.Â  The guidelines define gross 
  income for self-employed persons as:

gross receipts minus 
  ordinary and necessary expenses required for self-employment or business operation 
  . . . .Â  However, the court should exclude from those expenses amounts allowed 
  by the Internal Revenue Service for accelerated depreciation or investment tax 
  credits for purposes of the guidelines and add those amounts back in to determine 
  gross income.Â  In general, the court should carefully review income and expenses 
  from self-employment or operation of a business to determine actual levels of 
  gross income available to the parent to satisfy a child support obligation.Â  
  As may be apparent, this amount may differ from a determination of business 
  income for tax purposes.

  incurred by Mr. Rosen for his appearance at the first hearing ($2,885.25 
  [9] ) and four hours of fees for Mr. Rosen, Mrs. Rosen, and the paralegal 
  ($1,860) for their appearance at the second hearing.Â  Husband contends this 
  was error, and we agree.
Initially, we note that Husband was not at fault for Mrs. Rosenâ€™s 
  failure to appear at the first hearing.Â  Furthermore, he should not be penalized 
  for exercising his right to question the reasonableness and validity of Mrs. 
  Rosenâ€™s charges.Â  See Green v. Durham Life Ins. Co., 287 S.C. 
  197, 199, 336 S.E.2d 478, 480 (1985) (affirming the trial courtâ€™s decision not 
  to award attorneyâ€™s fees because respondent should not be penalized for litigating 
  a meritorious issue).Â  Thus, although the award of attorneyâ€™s fees is within 
  the discretion of the family court, 
  [10]  we reverse the award to the extent that it reimbursed Wifeâ€™s attorneys 
  for their fees from the second hearing.Â  It was an abuse of discretion to penalize 
  Husband for exercising his right to cross-examine Mrs. Rosen.Â Â Â Â Â  Husband is 
  therefore obligated to pay $2,885.25 rather than $4,725.25 for the fees incurred 
  by Wifeâ€™s attorneys for the contempt action.

  
    
    
      
        12.   
          
        Whether the family court erred in requiring Husband to pay uncovered medicals 
  within fourteen days of date of mailing or faxing  
          
      
    
    
  

The final order 
  of the family court requires Husband to pay Wife his portion of the uncovered 
  medical expenses within fourteen days of receiving an itemization by Wife.Â  
  After Husband failed to make timely payments, the family court found Husband 
  in contempt and ordered him to provide Wife with a facsimile number to which 
  she could send notice of expenses.Â  If Husband failed to provide a number, Wife 
  could serve notice by certified mail.Â  In either event, the court ordered Husband 
  to pay Wife his portion of the uncovered medical expenses within fourteen days 
  from which the notice was faxed or mailed.Â  Husband contends this was error.Â  
  We agree. 
Wife has not submitted 
  any evidence that this short time period is necessary to ensure a timely payment 
  of the bills or continued treatment of the child.Â  Therefore, we find fourteen 
  days from the time notice is faxed or mailed to be an unreasonably short period 
  of time given the nature and potential amount of the childâ€™s uncovered medical 
  expenses. See Rutherford v. Rutherford, 307 S.C. 199, 204, 414 
  S.E.2d 157, 160 (1992) (explaining that, in appeals from the family court, the 
  appellate court may find facts in accordance with its own view of the preponderance 
  of the evidence).Â  Instead, we find it equitable to both parties for Husband 
  to pay Wife his portion of the uncovered medical expenses within thirty days 
  of the date notice is faxed or mailed.Â  

  
    
    
      
        13.   
          
        Whether the family court erred in excluding testimony of Brian Clark  
          
      
    
    
  

Prior to trial, Wife moved to hold Husband in contempt for discovery abuses.Â  
  The family court found Husband had failed to comply with discovery and imposed 
  sanctions on Husband by awarding Wife $10,000 in attorneysâ€™ fees.Â  At trial, 
  Husband sought to introduce testimony from Brian Clark and certain exhibits 
  â€œto clear the air on compliance with discovery requests.â€Â  The family 
  court excluded the testimony, stating the issue had already been ruled upon.Â  
  On appeal, Husband argues the testimony was relevant to show that he had fully 
  complied with discovery.Â  Husband makes no argument regarding this issue and 
  cites no authority. [11] Â  Therefore, 
  we find the issue is abandoned on appeal.Â  See Glasscock, Inc. v. 
  Fidelity and Guar. Co., 348 S.C. 76, 81, 557 S.E.2d 689, 691 (Ct. App. 2001) 
  (â€œ[S]hort, conclusory statements made without supporting authority are deemed 
  abandoned on appeal and therefore not presented for review.â€). 

  
    
    
      
        14. 
   
        Whether the family court erred in awarding $10,000 attorneysâ€™ fees due 
  to abuse in discovery. 
   
      
    
    
  

As explained above, 
  the family court awarded Wife $10,000 in attorneysâ€™ fees after finding Husband 
  failed to comply with discovery.Â  Husband argues this was error.Â  We find this 
  issue was not timely appealed.
An order finding a party 
  in contempt is immediately appealable.Â  See Hooper v. Rockwell, 
  334 S.C. 281, 291, 513 S.E.2d 358, 364 (1999).Â  Because the order was not appealed 
  within the thirty-day limit under Rule 203(b)(3), SCACR, we dismiss this issue 
  on appeal.Â  See Rule 203(d)(3), SCACR (â€œIf the notice is not timely filed 
  or the filing fee is not paid in full, the appeal shall be dismissed, and shall 
  not be reinstated except as provided by Rule 231.â€).

  
    
    
      
        15.  
          
        Whether the family court judge erred in failing to recuse himself  
          
      
    
    
  

Husband argues 
  that the family court judge erred in failing to recuse himself from the hearing 
  on Wifeâ€™s action for contempt following the trial.Â  We disagree.Â  

The Code of Judicial Conduct requires a judge to â€˜disqualify himself in a proceeding 
  in which his impartiality might reasonably be questioned.â€™ Canon 3(C)(1) of 
  the Code of Judicial Conduct, Rule 501, SCACR. A judge must exercise sound judicial 
  discretion in determining whether his impartiality might reasonably be questioned. 
  Absent evidence of judicial prejudice, a judge's failure to disqualify himself 
  will not be reversed on appeal. It is not enough for a party seeking disqualification 
  to simply allege bias. The party must show some evidence of bias. Furthermore, 
  the alleged bias must be personal, as distinguished from judicial, in nature. 


Parker v. Shecut, 340 S.C. 460, 
  497, 531 S.E.2d 546, 566 (Ct. App. 2000), revâ€™d on other grounds by 349 
  S.C. 226, 562 S.E.2d 620 (2002).Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
Husband has failed to 
  present any evidence of bias by the family court judge.Â  It is not sufficient 
  for Husband to assert bias in the contempt action because the same judge presided 
  at the final hearing and ruled against him.Â  See Mallett v. Mallett, 
  323 S.C. 141, 147, 473 S.E.2d 804, 808 (Ct. App. 1996) (â€œThe fact a trial judge 
  ultimately rules against a litigant is not proof of prejudice by the judge, 
  even if it is later held the judge committed error in his rulings.â€).Â  Therefore, 
  we find no error in the family court judgeâ€™s failure to recuse himself. 

  B.   WIFEâ€™S CROSS-APPEAL
  
    
    
      
         1.   
        Whether the family courtâ€™s equitable 
  division of the property was erroneous.
      
    
    
  

Wife argues that 
  the family court judgeâ€™s equitable division of marital property was tainted 
  because he failed to address the fifteen factors listed in section 20-7-472 
  of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2003).Â  We disagree.
Section 20-7-472 sets forth factors 
  the family court should consider when equitably dividing a marital estate and 
  vests the family court with discretion to decide what weight to assign each 
  factor.Â  Jenkins v. Jenkins, 345 S.C. 88, 100, 545 S.E.2d 531,537 (Ct. 
  App. 2001).Â  â€œThis court will affirm the family court judge if it can be determined 
  that the judge addressed the factors under section 20-7-472 sufficiently for 
  us to conclude he was cognizant of the statutory factors.â€Â  Id.

 In this case, the family court judge specifically stated: â€œI have 
  applied the factors listed in Â§ 20-7-472 and relevant case law to divide the 
  property . . . .â€Â  Therefore, we are satisfied that the judge was cognizant 
  of the fifteen statutory factors set forth in section 20-7-472.Â  Accordingly, 
  we affirm the family courtâ€™s division of marital property.

  
    
    
      
         2.  
   
        Whether the family court erred in excluding a real estate lot 
   
      
    
    
  

Wife 
  argues the family court erred in excluding from the final order a parcel of 
  land that was marital property.Â  The specific lot allegedly excluded was â€œlot 
  A 39-4,â€ part of the marital property known as the Boozer-Arnal lots.Â  We find 
  this issue is not preserved.
At trial, Wife offered into evidence appraised values of the â€œBoozer-Arnal 
  lots.â€ However, the appraiser mistakenly appraised â€œlot A 38-4,â€ a lot that 
  Husband never owned, instead of â€œlot A 39-4,â€ which Husband owned.Â  In the final 
  order, the family court identifies the marital property to include the Boozer-Arnal 
  property, but specifically excludes the lot improperly appraised by Wifeâ€™s expert, 
  lot A 38-4.Â  In valuing these lots, the final order accepts the values of Wifeâ€™s 
  expert.Â  Because Wifeâ€™s expert did not value lot A 39-4, Wife did not receive 
  any of the lotâ€™s value, even though it was deemed marital property.
After the family court 
  issued its order, Wife did not file a Rule 59(e) motion raising the issue of 
  the value of lot A 39-4 to the family court judge.Â  Thus, this issue is not 
  preserved for appeal.Â  See Wilder Corp. v. Wilke, 330 S.C. 71, 
  76, 497 S.E.2d 731, 733 (1998); Halbersberg v. Berry, 302 S.C. 97, 103, 
  394 S.E.2d 7, 12 (1990) (finding the omission of the master in equity not preserved 
  because the party did not bring the omission to the attention of the master 
  through a proper motion).
CONCLUSION
We affirm the family 
  courtâ€™s order with respect to Wifeâ€™s income, award of pre-trial guardian fees, 
  equitable division, valuation of the Boozer-Arnal lots, and award of $10,000 
  in attorneysâ€™ fees on Wifeâ€™s action for contempt.Â  We also affirm the family 
  courtâ€™s exclusion of testimony by John. L. Hunter regarding Six Oaks Cemetery 
  and Brian Clark regarding discovery compliance.Â  Further, we affirm the family 
  court judgeâ€™s decision not to recuse himself from the contempt action following 
  the final hearing.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
We reverse the family courtâ€™s 
  decision to impute income to Husband and assign Husband income in the amount 
  of $59,010 annually.Â  We also reverse the family courtâ€™s requirement that Husband 
  pay all of the guardianâ€™s fees incurred during trial and find the parties should 
  bear that expense equally.Â  Further, we reverse the family courtâ€™s exclusion 
  of the trust corpuses; denial of Easter and summer visitation; award of $65,000 
  in attorneysâ€™ fees to Wife; award of $4,725.25 in attorneysâ€™ fees on the post-trial 
  contempt action; and requirement that Husband pay uncovered medical expenses 
  within fourteen days, finding thirty days to be more equitable.Â  Finally, we 
  reverse the award of $65,000 in attorneysâ€™ fees to Wife and order each party 
  to bear their own attorneysâ€™ fees.Â  
We remand the issues 
  of child support, uncovered medical bills, Easter and summer visitation, and 
  reimbursement for Husbandâ€™s trips to Brevard.Â  
AFFIRMED in part, 
  REVERSED in part, and REMANDED.
HUFF and KITTREDGE, 
  JJ., concur.

 
   
    [1]  The partiesâ€™ child reached forty-three months of age on February 
    7, 2003.Â  Nevertheless, this court learned during oral argument in September 
    of 2004 that Husband is still not exercising weekend visitation in Hilton 
    Head.

 
   
    [2]  Husbandâ€™s monthly income as reflected on his financial declaration 
    was $3,656.56.Â  This income plus the additional imputed income total $9,060.12.

 
   
    [3]  Because these parties have such a litigious history, we have attempted 
    to remand as few issues as possible.Â  However, we are not able to calculate 
    child support ourselves because the record does not reflect how much Wife 
    pays each month for the childâ€™s health insurance.

 
   
    [4]  The trust document does not appear in the record.Â  Wifeâ€™s expert 
    testified that Henry Bernheim is the trustee, however, Husbandâ€™s expert testified 
    that the trust document suggested Wife was a co-trustee with Bernheim.Â  

 
   
    [5]  Evidence in the record indicated that Wife presently lives â€œdown 
    the streetâ€ from the South Carolina border.Â  

 
   
    [6]  Wife has also received payment from the trust from sale proceeds 
    of Six Oaks Cemetery, an asset contained in the trust corpus.

 
   
    [7]  This trust corpus has contained some significant assets in the past, 
    including the Umbro corporation.Â  After its sale, Wife received approximately 
    $134,000 from the trust.Â  

 
   
    [8]  At trial, the guardian suggested Wife pay Husband $300 per month 
    to help defray the cost of exercising visitation in Brevard.Â Â  On appeal, 
    Husband argues the family court abused its discretion in failing to follow 
    this recommendation.Â  Because we reverse and remand the issue of travel costs 
    based on the family courtâ€™s failure to consider the trust corpuses, we need 
    not address this issue.Â  See Futch v. McAllister Towing of Georgetown, 
    Inc., 335 S.C. 598, 613, 518 S.E.2d 591, 598 (1999) (explaining that the 
    appellate court need not address remaining issues when disposition of prior 
    issues is dispositive).Â  Husband also argues that the issue of child support 
    should be reversed and remanded because the family court failed to consider 
    the expenses he incurred each time he exercised visitation in Brevard.Â  However, 
    this argument was not raised to the family court at trial, and therefore is 
    not preserved for appeal.Â  See Wilder Corp. v. Wilke, 330 S.C. 
    71, 76, 497 S.E.2d 731, 733 (1998).

 
   
    [9]  In calculating the fees incurred by Mr. Rosen at the first hearing, 
    the family court subtracted the amount estimated by Mrs. Rosenâ€™s appearance 
    at the hearing, $875, from the total submitted in the affidavit, $2,635.25, 
    and added Mr. Rosenâ€™s fee for his appearance, $1,125, totaling $2,885.25.Â  
    Added to this was the $1,860 in attorneysâ€™ and paralegal fees.Â  Although this 
    sum comes to $4,745.25, the family court awarded $4,725.25.

 
   
    [10]  Lindsay v. Lindsay, 328 S.C. 329, 345-46, 491 S.E.2d 583, 
    592 (Ct. App. 1997).

 
   
    [11]  In his reply brief, Husband asserts that this argument is not abandoned 
    on appeal because it is intimately intertwined with issue number fifteen on 
    appeal, which was adequately argued and briefed.Â  Even if this issue is related 
    to issue fifteen, Husband has failed to make any reference to the relevancy 
    of Brian Clarkâ€™s testimony or exhibits in issue fifteen.Â  Further, Husband 
    cites to no authority with respect to the relevancy of Brian Clarkâ€™s testimony 
    or exhibits in issue fifteen.Â

title: Pinion v. Pinion
description: Affirms the trial court's refusal to charge proof of an overt act is required in a case where it is alleged a wife conspired to kill her husband and thus should not benefit from his death.
text:
Pinion v. Pinion


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Lloyd Pinion, by Amanda Montague, as Personal Representative for Estate 
        of Lloyd Pinion and Helen Pinion, Respondents,
v.
Edie J. Pinion, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Pickens County
John C. Few, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 3944
Heard January 12, 2005 â€“ Filed February 
  7, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Michael Anthony Andrews, of Easley, for Appellant.
Perry Hudson Gravely, of Pickens, for Respondents.
      
    
  

STILWELL, J.: Â South Carolina Code section 62-2-803 prevents a person 
  who feloniously and intentionally kills another from benefiting from the death, 
  from either the deceasedâ€™s estate or contractual arrangements the deceased had, 
  such as life insurance.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 62-2-803 (1987).Â  Our supreme court 
  has previously held the statute is broad enough to cover conspiracy such that 
  a conspirator would be barred from benefiting from the death.Â  Wilson v. 
  Wilson, 319 S.C. 370, 372-73, 461 S.E.2d 816, 817 (1995).Â  In this case 
  brought under section 62-2-803, the sole issue presented is whether the trial 
  court correctly refused to charge the jury that proof of an overt act was required 
  to prove the alleged conspiracy.Â  We affirm the trial courtâ€™s refusal to so 
  instruct the jury. 
BACKGROUND
Following their sonâ€™s murder, Lloyd and Helen Pinion brought this action against 
  their sonâ€™s widow, Edie Pinion, to prevent her from benefiting from his death.Â  
  Based on a juryâ€™s finding that Edie had conspired with another person to feloniously 
  and intentionally kill her husband, 
  [1]  the court ordered she could not be an heir or beneficiary from or through 
  his estate and was not entitled to collect his life insurance proceeds, retirement 
  benefits, or similar contractual payments.Â  
DISCUSSION
A criminal conspiracy is the combination of two or more persons â€œfor 
  the purpose of accomplishing an unlawful object or lawful object by unlawful 
  means.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-17-410 (2003).Â  â€œIt may be proven by the specific 
  overt acts done in furtherance of the conspiracy but the crime is the agreement.â€Â  
  State v. Buckmon, 347 S.C. 316, 323, 555 S.E.2d 402, 405 (2001).Â  Under 
  South Carolina law, criminal conspiracy does not require overt acts.Â  State 
  v. Wilson, 315 S.C. 289, 294, 433 S.E.2d 864, 867-68 (1993).Â  A civil conspiracy 
  is the combination of two or more persons to injure a plaintiff and cause him 
  special injuries thereby.Â  In contrast with a criminal conspiracy, a civil conspiracy 
  is actionable only if overt acts pursuant to the conspiracy proximately cause 
  damage to the plaintiff.Â  Future Group, II v. Nationsbank, 324 S.C. 89, 
  100, 478 S.E.2d 45, 50-51 (1996).Â  Edie sought a jury charge based on the law 
  of civil conspiracy.Â  However, section 62-2-803, although not itself a criminal 
  statute, applies only to situations where the deceased was intentionally and 
  feloniously killed, which is a crime.Â  Thus, it follows any conspiracy triggering 
  this statute would also be criminal, rather than civil.Â  Our conclusion is supported 
  by Wilson v. Wilson, the case in which our supreme court held the statute 
  was broad enough to cover conspiracy.Â  In that case, the court held â€œ[w]hile 
  conspiracy could be sufficient to invoke the statute, the elements of criminal 
  conspiracy were not established in this instance to support a finding that 
  petitioner feloniously and intentionally killed the insured.â€Â  Wilson, 
  319 S.C. at 373, 461 S.E.2d at 817 (emphasis added and footnote listing the 
  elements of criminal conspiracy omitted).Â  This clearly shows our supreme court 
  concluded any conspiracy triggering the application of this statute would be 
  criminal.Â  
Nevertheless, Edie contends because this is a civil 
  action with a civil burden of proof, the civil rather than criminal definition 
  of conspiracy should apply.Â  Subsection (e) of section 62-2-803 provides a conviction 
  for felonious and intentional killing is conclusive proof under the statute.Â  
  In the absence of a conviction, subsection (e) states the civil â€œpreponderance 
  of evidenceâ€ standard applies.Â  However, use of a civil burden of proof does 
  not negate the fact the triggering event is the criminal act of a â€œfelonious 
  and intentional killing.â€Â  
Because an overt act is not required to establish criminal conspiracy, 
  and the statute applies to one who criminally conspires to commit a felonious 
  and intentional killing, the trial court properly refused to instruct the jury 
  that an overt act was required in this case.
 AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON and SHORT, JJ., concur.

 
   [1] Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
    Edieâ€™s son, Matt Baum, was convicted of the murder.Â

title: S.C. Labor Limited v. Eastern Tree Service
description: This is an appeal of a grant of summary judgment in an action for collection on an agreement for contract labor.  Eastern Tree Service argues there is a genuine issue of material fact as to whether SC Labor Ltd. was entitled to judgment as a matter of law and as to the amount it was entitled to recover.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
S.C. Labor Limited, LLC, Respondent,
v.
Eastern Tree Service, Inc., Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Spartanburg County
Â Larry R. Patterson, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 3945Â Â 
Heard January 11, 2005 â€“ Filed February 14, 2005 

REVERSED and REMANDED


  
    
      
Rhett D. Burne and Matthew P. Turner, both of Laurens, for Appellant.
C. Richard Stewart, of Greenville, for Respondent.
      
    
  

GOOLSBY, J.:Â  South Carolina Labor Limited, LLC, a corporation that 
  provides temporary workers to businesses, sued Eastern Tree Service, Inc., alleging 
  Tree Service failed to pay Labor Limited for workers.Â  Labor Limited filed a 
  motion for summary judgment.Â  In support of the motion, Labor Limited submitted 
  invoices as evidence of the existence of an agreement and as evidence of the 
  amount of payment Tree Service owed.Â  In opposition, Tree Service submitted 
  the affidavits and depositions of Walter T. Caldwell, who purchased Tree Service 
  during a time it did business with Labor Limited, and John Martin, Jr., a Tree 
  Service manager.Â  In the affidavits and depositions, Caldwell and Martin questioned 
  the credibility of the Labor Limited invoices based on their knowledge of the 
  normal business practices of Tree Service.Â  The trial court granted the summary 
  judgment motion and entered judgment in favor of Labor Limited.Â  Tree Service 
  filed a motion to alter or amend pursuant to Rule 59(e), SCRCP, and the trial 
  court denied the motion.Â  Tree Service appeals.Â  We reverse. 
â€œWhen reviewing the grant of summary judgment, the appellate court 
  applies the same standard applied by the trial court pursuant to Rule 56(c), 
  SCRCP.â€Â  Fleming v. Rose, 350 S.C. 488, 494, 567 S.E.2d 857, 860 
  (2002). â€œSummary judgment is appropriate when it is clear that there is no genuine 
  issue of material fact and that the moving party is entitled to a judgment as 
  a matter of law.â€ Baird v. Charleston County, 333 S.C. 519, 529, 
  511 S.E.2d 69, 74 (1999).Â  
In granting Labor 
  Limited summary judgment, the trial court found the affidavits and depositions 
  offered by Tree Service did not create a genuine issue of material fact as to 
  the number of workers Labor Limited supplied Tree Service and the number of 
  hours they worked.Â  In reaching this conclusion, the trial court found the affidavits 
  were not in conformity with the requirements of Rule 56(e), SCRCP, in that neither 
  Caldwell nor Martin had personal knowledge â€œof what transpired between [Labor 
  Limited] and [Tree Service]â€ but rather â€œ[t]he affidavits expressed opinion 
  as to what those individuals felt should have been done.â€Â  
Tree Service argues 
  the trial court erred in finding Caldwellâ€™s and Martinâ€™s affidavits were not 
  based on personal knowledge.Â  We agree. 
Rule 56(e) provides, â€œaffidavits shall be made on personal knowledge, [and] 
  shall set forth such facts as would be admissible in evidence.â€Â  See 
  Hall v. Fedor, 349 S.C. 169, 175, 561 S.E.2d 654, 657 (Ct. App. 2002) 
  (holding â€œmaterials used to support or refute a motion for summary judgment 
  must be those which would be admissible in evidenceâ€).Â  
The information included in the affidavits at issue, as well as the information 
  supplied by Caldwell and Martin in their depositions, are based on personal 
  knowledge and, moreover, are admissible in evidence to counter the evidence 
  supplied by Labor Limited as to the number of workers it furnished Tree Service 
  and the number of hours these workers performed labor for Tree Service.Â  Statements 
  as to a routine practice of an organization are admissible to prove what was 
  done in a given situation was in conformity with routine practice.Â  Park 
  Club, Inc. v. Resolution Trust Corp., 967 F.2d 1053 (5th Cir. 
  1992); see Danny R. Collins, South Carolina Evidence Â§9.3, 252-253, 
  257-258 (2d. ed., South Carolina Bar 2000); Russell v. Pitts, 123 S.E.2d 
  708, 710 (Ga. Ct. App. 1961) (â€œ[I]t is generally permissible to allow a witness 
  to testify from his own knowledge as to the usual custom or course of dealing 
  involving the business routine of the party involved.â€); Micke v. Jack Walters 
  & Sons Corp., 234 N.W.2d 347 (Wis. 1975) (finding evidence of a corporationâ€™s 
  routine practice was relevant and properly admitted to determine whether aÂ  
  manager explained the corporationâ€™s policy concerning commissions to a prior 
  employee);Â  Spartan Grain & Mill Co. v. Ayers, 517 F.2d 214 (5th 
  Cir. 1975) (holding evidence of how the seller customarily handled eggs was 
  improperly excluded).Â  Furthermore, evidence of custom and practice can be used 
  to rebut evidence of fact.Â  See Park Club, 967 F.2d at 1057; Meyer 
  v. United States, 638 F.2d 155 (10th Cir. 1981) (holding evidence 
  that a dentist customarily warned his patients of the risks of surgery was adequate 
  to rebut a patientâ€™s testimony that the dentist did not warn her).
Labor Limited supplied weekly invoices that included the number of workers, 
  the number of hours each worker labored, the rate of pay, and the total amount 
  due.Â  Most of the invoices show three workers labored forty hours.
Caldwell, as an owner of Tree Service during a time it did business with Labor 
  Limited, is qualified to describe the routine practices of Tree Service to counter 
  the invoices supplied by Labor Limited.Â  Caldwell stated in his deposition Tree 
  Service employees typically worked only four days a week.Â  
Martin, who worked for Tree Service during the time Labor Limited supplied 
  workers to Tree Service and later became its manager, personally ordered workers 
  from Labor Limited on several occasions.Â  In his affidavit, he stated that Tree 
  Service, when using Labor Limited workers, customarily employed two workers 
  â€œat the mostâ€ and these workers â€œwould not have worked ten hour days on most 
  occasions.â€ 
Although the question 
  is a close one, we cannot say that a rational trier of fact could not find that 
  the number of Labor Limited workers retained by Tree Service and the number 
  of hours they worked were less than the Labor Limited invoices show.Â  
REVERSED and REMANDED. [1] 
HEARN, C.J., and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

 
   [1]  Tree Service also raises an issue concerning the Dead Manâ€™s 
    Statute, S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 19-11-20 (2003). We do not address this issue because 
    we do not give advisory opinions. See Springob v. Farrar, 
    334 S.C. 585, 592, 514 S.E.2d 135, 139 (Ct. App. 1999).

description: Affirms trial court's ruling that (1) alleged agreement for severance allowance was not enforceable pursuant to Virginia law and (2) alleged discovery abuses did not justify the grant of a new trial.
text:
Conway v. Charleston Lincoln Mercury 


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
John C. Conway, Jr., Appellant,
v.
Charleston Lincoln Mercury Inc. and Haywood B. Hyman, Sr.,
Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
Gerald C. Smoak, Sr., Circuit Court 
  Judge

Opinion No. 3946
Heard December 8, 2004 â€“ Filed February 
  14, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
George Hunter McMaster 
  and Nelda T. Smyrl, both of Columbia, for Appellant.
G. Dana Sinkler, of Charleston, 
  for Respondents.
      
    
  

STILWELL, J.:Â  John Conway sued Charleston 
  Lincoln Mercury (CLM) and Haywood Hyman, its sole shareholder and president, 
  alleging breach of contract, unpaid wages, fraud, and constructive fraud arising 
  from an alleged oral agreement between Hyman and Conway to pay Conway a severance 
  allowance.Â  After a bench trial, the trial court issued an order finding for 
  CLM and Hyman on all claims.Â  We affirm.Â  
BACKGROUND
CLM initially hired Conway as an independent contractor 
  when Hyman was negotiating to sell the company.Â  After one negotiation fell 
  through, Conway and another employee, Al Shuman, discussed purchasing CLM.Â  
  However, on a trip to Hymanâ€™s home in Richmond, Virginia, Hyman informed Conway 
  he did not intend to sell the company to Conway and Shuman and was in talks 
  with another party.Â  Conway alleges Hyman asked him to work to get the company 
  ready for sale and to keep Shuman from leaving the company.Â  Conway contends 
  Hyman promised him $120,000 in severance in exchange for his efforts should 
  he not be offered employment comparable to his then employment following a sale.Â  
  Conway testified he prepared a memorandum memorializing the agreement he made 
  with Hyman.Â  Conway asserts he presented a copy of this memorandum to Hyman, 
  but Hyman did not sign it.Â  Later, Conway drafted another memorandum, entitled 
  â€œMemorandum to File,â€ setting forth his version of the events surrounding the 
  agreement and reciting the terms of the agreement as presented to Hyman.Â  Conway 
  placed a copy of this memorandum in his personnel file where a CLM accounts 
  payable clerk found it approximately a year later.Â  
Eventually, another buyer was identified and a 
  contract was executed for the sale of CLMâ€™s assets.Â  After the sale closed, 
  Conway continued his employment with the dealership for a short time as an independent 
  contractor, but never became a full-time employee of the new owner.Â  
Conway then filed this action, alleging 
  CLM and Hyman failed to pay him the $120,000 severance as promised in the oral 
  agreement.Â  Following a non-jury trial, the court ruled in favor of CLM and 
  Hyman on all of Conwayâ€™s claims.Â  Among other things, the trial court ruled 
  no valid contract between the parties for severance ever existed because the 
  written agreement was never executed as Conway anticipated.Â  The court also 
  denied Conwayâ€™s post-trial motions.Â  
DISCUSSION
I.Â  Existence of an Oral Contract
Conway contends the 
  trial court erred in not finding an oral contract existed between he and CLM.Â  
  We disagree.Â  
An action for breach of contract seeking damages 
  is an action at law.Â  Sterling Dev. Co. v. Collins, 309 S.C. 237, 240, 421 S.E.2d 402, 404 (1992).Â  In an action at law 
  tried without a jury, the trial courtâ€™s factual findings will not be disturbed 
  on appeal unless those findings are wholly unsupported by the evidence or controlled 
  by error of law.Â  Gordon v. Colonial Ins. Co. of California, 
  342 S.C. 152, 155, 536 S.E.2d 376, 378 (Ct. App. 2000).Â 
Because Conway alleges he and Hyman formed the 
  contract in Virginia, Virginia law must be applied to determine whether a valid 
  contract was formed.Â  Unisun Ins. Co. v. Hertz Rental Corp., 312 S.C. 
  549, 551-52, 436 S.E.2d 182, 184 (Ct. App. 1993) (â€œUnless the parties agree 
  to a different rule, the validity and interpretation of a contract is ordinarily 
  to be determined by the law of the state in which the contract was made.â€).Â  
  Under Virginia law, a writing is not always necessary to form a valid contract.Â  
  Harris v. Citizen Bank & Trust Co., 200 S.E. 652, 665 (Va. 1939).Â  
  However, â€œ[i]f it be understood that its terms are to be reduced to writing 
  as an ultimate expression of conclusions reached . . . then a writing is necessary.â€Â  
  Id. at 665.Â  
The trial courtâ€™s conclusion that no valid agreement 
  existed is supported by the evidence.Â  The record indicates the parties meant 
  for the agreement to be reduced to writing as a prerequisite to the formation 
  of a contract.Â  Conway testified that after his conversation with Hyman regarding 
  the payment of severance, Conway reduced the terms of that agreement to writing 
  and gave Hyman a copy the next morning.Â  Conway admitted Hyman told him he was 
  not feeling well and could not read it at that time.Â  
Conwayâ€™s memo to file also contains evidence of 
  the partiesâ€™ intentions.Â  The memoâ€™s subject line states:Â  â€œEmployment Agreements 
  & Severance Pay.â€Â  Conway testified he created the document after his trip 
  to Richmond and it â€œmemorialized the agreement Mr. Hyman and I came to [during 
  his trip].â€Â  The memo states:Â  

Mr. Conway presented Mr. Hyman a new written Employment 
  Agreement for himself as well as a Memorandum outlining the Estate and Business 
  Planning that had been discussed previously with Mr. Douglas.Â  Mr. Hyman started 
  to look the documents over and then said that he wasnâ€™t feeling well and that 
  he couldnâ€™t go through them right then because he wasnâ€™t feeling well and was 
  tired.Â  He said he would look them over later and get back to Mr. Conway, since 
  he (Mr. Conway) was preparing to leave to return to Charleston.Â  

(Emphasis added.)Â  The memorandum then recites the 
  â€œtext of the written text of the Employment Agreement.â€Â  The terms of this Employment 
  Agreement included Conwayâ€™s right to receive a $120,000 severance at the closing 
  of the sale of CLM if CLM were unable to offer him continued employment.Â  
Additionally, Conwayâ€™s wife, Carol Conway, testified 
  she was present when the alleged oral agreement was formed.Â  She confirmed Conway 
  produced a written memo the next day that included the points he and Hyman discussed.Â  
  She stated Conway gave a copy of the memo along with other documents to Hyman 
  in her presence and said Mr. Hyman remarked â€œhe didnâ€™t feel well.Â  That he didnâ€™t 
  want to read over anything like that because he was feeling bad and I assume 
  that he really was and that he would sign it, just to leave the papers and he 
  would sign them and send them to John.Â  And that was it.â€Â  
The trial court could infer from this evidence 
  that the parties presumed their oral negotiations were to be reduced to writing 
  before a contract was formed.Â  Additionally, according to the memo Conway placed 
  in the file, the terms of the agreement were in fact reduced to writing in the 
  form of an employment agreement.Â  Therefore, Conwayâ€™s testimony, his wifeâ€™s 
  testimony, and the file memo contemplating a written agreement, sufficiently 
  support the trial courtâ€™s finding that the parties intended for the agreement 
  to be reduced to writing.Â  Because the trial court found the prerequisite of 
  a written agreement was not satisfied, it properly determined a valid agreement 
  did not exist. [1] Â  
II.Â  Hymanâ€™s Deposition
As part of his argument that an oral agreement 
  existed, Conway contends the trial court erred in allowing the defense to admit 
  Hymanâ€™s deposition in lieu of testimony.Â  The trial court allowed the deposition 
  after the defense submitted a physicianâ€™s letter documenting Hymanâ€™s Alzheimerâ€™s 
  disease and significant deterioration of his memory.Â  Conway complains the deposition 
  was the sole evidence in support of the position of CLM and Hyman that no valid 
  agreement existed and should not have been admitted.Â  We disagree.Â  
The decision to admit or exclude evidence is within 
  the trial courtâ€™s sound discretion and will not be disturbed on appeal absent 
  an abuse of discretion.Â  Gamble v. Intâ€™l Paper Realty Corp. of South Carolina, 
  323 S.C. 367, 373, 474 S.E.2d 438, 441 (1996).Â  To warrant a reversal based 
  on the admission of evidence, the appellant must show both error and resulting 
  prejudice.Â  Commerce Ctr. of Greenville, Inc. v. W. Powers McElveen 
  & Assocs. Inc., 347 S.C. 
  545, 559, 556 S.E.2d 718, 726 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  When improperly admitted evidence 
  is merely cumulative, no prejudice exists, and therefore, the admission is not 
  reversible error.Â  Creech v. South Carolina Wildlife & Marine 
  Res. Depâ€™t, 328 S.C. 24, 35, 491 S.E.2d 571, 576 
  (1997).Â  
Regardless of whether the trial court properly 
  admitted Hymanâ€™s deposition, Conway did not suffer prejudice from its admission.Â  
  This evidence was merely cumulative to the evidence discussed above.Â  Conwayâ€™s 
  own testimony, his wifeâ€™s testimony, and the Memorandum to File support the 
  courtâ€™s finding that no valid agreement existed.Â  In addition, when the court 
  ruled the deposition admissible, it specifically informed the parties they were 
  free to call Hyman as a witness.Â  Conway chose to forgo this opportunity. Â Therefore, 
  we find no basis for reversal.Â  
III.Â  Alleged Discovery Abuses
After trial, Conway moved for relief 
  from judgment on several grounds under Rule 60, SCRCP, including newly discovered 
  evidence.Â  At the hearing on the motion, Conway asked for a new trial and argued 
  Hyman and CLM had engaged in a pattern of discovery abuses.Â  The trial court 
  denied Conwayâ€™s motion.Â  Conway argues the courtâ€™s ruling as to discovery abuses 
  was error.Â  We disagree. 
Discovery rights afford a trial attorney the opportunity to prepare for trial.Â  
  Samples v. Mitchell, 329 S.C. 105, 113-14, 495 S.E.2d 213, 217 (Ct. App. 
  1997).Â  Where these rights are not accorded, prejudice is presumed and unless 
  the party that failed to comply establishes a lack of prejudice, reversal is 
  required.Â  Id. at 114, 495 S.E.2d at 217.
Conway asserts three instances of discovery abuse by CLM and Hyman.Â  They 
  neither individually nor collectively support his request for a new trial.Â  

First, he contends the defendants should have apprised him of Hymanâ€™s medical 
  condition or provided him with a copy of his doctorâ€™s letter prior to trial.Â  
  Assuming this information should have been revealed to Conway pretrial, we are 
  unable to discern how advance warning of Hymanâ€™s condition would have aided 
  Conway or made any difference in the case.Â  There is no indication that advance 
  knowledge of Hymanâ€™s ailment would have assisted Conway in doing anything more 
  than he did.Â  
Next, Conway points to a document the defense offered though an expert witness 
  that had never been provided to Conway during discovery.Â  Although the document 
  was initially admitted, the trial court later struck it pursuant to Conwayâ€™s 
  motion to strike.Â  Because the document was stricken from the record and there 
  is no indication that it was relied on by the trial court in its decision, we 
  find no prejudice.
Conwayâ€™s final assertion of discovery abuse concerns 
  the defenseâ€™s failure to provide him with notes and a memo written by James 
  Starnes, a consultant Hyman hired to investigate CLMâ€™s outstanding liabilities.Â  
  Conway alleges an excerpt from Starnesâ€™ handwritten notes shows three attorneys 
  who represented the defendants, including one who also served as a fact witness 
  in the case, all believed Conway was entitled to severance.Â  CLM and Hyman had 
  listed Starnes as a fact witness several months before trial, but later decided 
  not to call him.Â  After learning he would not be called, Conway cancelled his 
  scheduled deposition of Starnes.Â  
After trial, as a result of a case Al Shuman brought 
  against CLM, Conway discovered Starnesâ€™ documents.Â  The passage in question 
  is from Starnesâ€™ handwritten notes and reads:

  
    
    
      
         J.C.
      
    
    
      
        Ry [Marchant] thinks Alâ€™s entitled to the 
  severance
    
    
    
      Zuckerman Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  "Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  "Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
  Â  "Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Â  "Â Â  " Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â "
    
    
      Thompson Â Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  "Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  "Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Â  "Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
  Â  "Â Â  " Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â "
    
    
    
  

Conway argues the note suggests three of Hyman and 
  CLMâ€™s attorneys (Marchant, Zuckerman, and Thompson) believed Conway was entitled 
  to a severance and the defense made a deliberate decision to withhold this information.Â  
  First, we note the passage originally said â€œAlâ€™s entitled to severanceâ€ and 
  it is not clear who struck Al and inserted J.C. or when this took place.Â  Furthermore, 
  the passage comes from a portion of the notes Starnes labeled â€œConversation 
  w/J. Conway.â€Â  A thorough review of the notes and a comparison of them to the 
  memo Starnes prepared based on the notes clearly indicate the source of the 
  statements was Conway himself, rather than the three attorneys referenced.Â  
  This deduction is supported by affidavits of Starnes and Marchant.Â  In his affidavit, 
  Marchant denied ever telling Starnes or anyone else that he believed Conway 
  was entitled to severance pay.Â  Starnes, in his affidavit, stated the disputed 
  passage refers to statements Conway made to him and not to comments made by 
  Marchant, Zuckerman, or Thompson.Â  He further stated none of the three attorneys 
  ever told him they believed Conway was entitled to the severance.Â  Conway was 
  not prejudiced by the defenseâ€™s failure to produce Starnesâ€™ documents containing 
  Conwayâ€™s own self-serving statements.
Through their argument and the 
  record, Hyman and CLM have established Conway was not prejudiced by any of the 
  discovery abuses he alleges occurred.Â  The trial court properly denied Conwayâ€™s 
  motion for a new trial.
 AFFIRMED.Â  
 ANDERSON and SHORT, 
  JJ., concur.

 
   [1] Because we affirm the trial court on this issue, we need not 
    address Conwayâ€™s argument that the trial court erred in concluding severance 
    pay is not wages under S.C. Code Ann. section 41-10-80 (Supp. 2004).Â
