description: Global Sun-Pools, Inc. and Ken Darwin appeal from the circuit court's order denying their motion to compel arbitration.
text:
Chassereau v. Global-Sun Pools, Inc.


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Vicki F. Chassereau, Respondent,
v.
Global-Sun Pools, Inc. and Ken Darwin, Appellants.
      
    
  


Appeal From Hampton County
Â Perry M. Buckner, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No.Â  3947
Heard January 11, 2005 â€“ Filed February 
  22, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Michael H. Montgomery and Frank S. Potts, both of Columbia, for Appellants.
John E. Parker, of Hampton, for Respondent.
      
    
  

GOOLSBY, J.:Â  Global Sun-Pools, Inc. and Ken Darwin appeal from the 
  circuit courtâ€™s order denying their motion to compel arbitration.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
On April 19, 2003, Vicki Chassereau and Global-Sun Pools signed a 
  contract for the construction of an aboveground pool at Chassereauâ€™s residence 
  in Varnville, South Carolina.Â  The purchase price was $6,765.00.Â  The contract 
  contained an arbitration provision, more fully described below, that requires 
  any arbitrable dispute to be conducted not in Varnville, South Carolina, but 
  in Carson City, Nevada.Â  At the same time, Chassereau signed an installment 
  sales contract to finance the transaction.Â  
Shortly after Global-Sun Pools completed construction, Chassereau 
  began experiencing problems with the pool.Â  She requested a part from Global-Sun 
  Pools so the pool would function properly.Â  After Global-Sun Pools failed either 
  to replace the part or to repair the pool, Chassereau stopped making payments 
  on the pool.Â Â Â  
On September 18, 2003, Chassereau filed a complaint against the appellants 
  alleging that, after she stopped making payments, Ken Darwin and other employees 
  of Global-Sun Pools made a series of harassing and intimidating telephone calls 
  to her workplace, Harper Skilled Nursing Facility.Â  Chassereau asserted Darwin 
  and the other employees left â€œmessages disclosing [her] private and personal 
  finances to her co-employeesâ€ and â€œmade false and defamatory statements about 
  [her] during their conversations with [her] co-employees and supervisor.â€Â  Chassereau 
  specifically alleged that Darwin â€œfalsely and with malice defamed [her] by accusing 
  her of dishonestyâ€ in conversations with her supervisor, co-employees, and relatives.Â  
  Darwin also allegedly â€œmade numerous [tele]phone callsâ€ to Chassereau â€œin an 
  effort to intimidate and harass herâ€ and made harassing telephone calls to Chassereauâ€™s 
  relatives.Â  Chassereau asserted the calls continued despite her repeated requests 
  that the harassment stop and her supervisorâ€™s request that the calls to their 
  place of employment cease.Â  
In her complaint, Chassereau asserted causes of action for (1) defamation; 
  (2) violation of South Carolina law prohibiting unlawful use of a telephone, 
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-17-430 (2003) [1] ; and (3) intentional infliction of emotional 
  distress.Â  
The appellants filed a motion to stay and to compel arbitration, 
  asserting clauses contained in the construction contract and the installment 
  sales contract require arbitration.Â  After a hearing, the circuit court denied 
  the motion, finding â€œ[t]he complaint is based upon tortious conduct of the employees 
  of [Global-Sun Pools] unrelated to the contractâ€ and â€œthe allegations of the 
  complaint do not arise out of nor do they relate to the contract[.]â€Â  This appeal 
  followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The question whether a claim is subject to arbitration is a matter for judicial 
  determination, unless the parties have provided otherwise. 
  [2] Â  Appeal from the denial of a motion to compel arbitration is subject 
  to de novo review. [3] Â Â Â Â Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
The appellants contend the circuit court erred in refusing to stay 
  the legal action and to compel arbitration of Chassereauâ€™s claims because the 
  contracts mandate arbitration and the claims are so interwoven with the contracts 
  that the claims could not be maintained separately. 
Arbitration is a matter of contract, and a party cannot be required 
  to submit to arbitration any dispute that the party has not agreed to submit. 
  [4] Â  â€œArbitration rests on the agreement of the parties, and the range 
  of issues that can be arbitrated is restricted by the terms of the agreement.â€ [5] Â  
 â€œTo decide whether an arbitration agreement encompasses a dispute 
  a court must determine whether the factual allegations underlying the claim 
  are within the scope of the broad arbitration clause, regardless of the label 
  assigned to the claim.â€ [6] Â  
  â€œAny doubts concerning the scope of arbitration should be resolved in favor 
  of arbitration.â€ [7] Â  
In the current appeal, the partiesâ€™ construction contract contains 
  an arbitration provision that, because of its length and format, taxes the eyes.Â  
  It states in pertinent part:

SECTION G) BINDING ARBITRATION AGREEMENT:Â  ANY DISPUTES ARISING IN ANY MANNER 
  RELATING TO THIS AGREEMENT THAT CANNOT BE RESOLVED BY NEGOTIATION BETWEEN THE 
  PARTIES SHALL BE SUBJECTED TO MANDATORY, EXCLUSIVE AND BINDING ARBITRATION IN 
  CARSON CITY, NEVADA . . . .Â  THE SOLE AND EXCLUSIVE REMEDY OF THE PURCHASER 
  AND THE OBLIGATION OF THE DEALER FOR THE MATTERS SET FORTH HEREIN WHETHER ON 
  WARRANTY, CONTRACT, NEGLIGENCE OR STRICT LIABILITY, IS THE REPAIR OF THE DEFECT.Â  
  THE DEALER SHALL IN NO WAY BE LIABLE FOR SPECIAL OR CONSEQUENTIAL DAMAGES. . 
  . .Â  THE COURT SHALL DECIDE WHETHER AN AGREEMENT TO ARBITRATE EXISTS OR A CONTROVERSY 
  IS SUBJECT TO ANY AGREEMENT TO ARBITRATE.  [8] Â  

The language at 
  issue here is the phrase â€œany disputes arising in any manner relating to this 
  agreement.â€Â Â Â  
We recently held that â€œa clause compelling arbitration for any claim â€˜arising 
  out of or relating to this agreementâ€™ may cover disputes outside the agreement, 
  but only if those disputes relate to the subject matter of that agreement.â€ 
  [9] Â  We observed that, the mere fact that an arbitration clause could apply 
  to matters beyond the express scope of the underlying contract did not imply 
  that arbitration would be required for every dispute between the parties. [10] Â  We distinguished this language from clauses 
  compelling arbitration of any matter arising out of the â€œrelationship of the 
  parties.â€Â  In the latter case, it would not matter whether a claim related to 
  a contract containing an arbitration clause or not. [11] Â  Rather, the only question would be whether the claim concerned 
  the relationship of the parties. 
  [12] Â  
Our supreme court has held that â€œ[a] broadly-worded arbitration clause applies 
  to disputes that do not arise under the governing contract when a â€˜significant 
  relationshipâ€™ exists between the asserted claims and the contract in which the 
  arbitration clause is contained.â€ [13] Â  The court noted the following test has been 
  used in some jurisdictions to determine whether a particular tort claim falls 
  within the scope of an agreement to arbitrate:Â  

The test is based on a determination whether the particular tort claim is so 
  interwoven with the contract that it could not stand alone.Â  If the tort and 
  contract claims are so interwoven, both are arbitrable.Â  On the other hand, 
  if the tort claim is completely independent of the contract and could be maintained 
  without reference to the contract, the tort claim is not arbitrable. [14] 

In our opinion, Chassereauâ€™s claims for defamation, unlawful use of a telephone, 
  and intentional infliction of emotional distress cannot be considered claims 
  â€œarising out ofâ€ the contract [15]  any more than would a claim that Darwin and 
  other employees of Global-Sun Pools had gone to Chassereauâ€™s workplace and verbally 
  or physically attacked her. 
Â Not only do Chassereauâ€™s claims involve actions taken by the appellants that 
  do not arise out of the contract between Chassereau and Global-Sun Pools, the 
  claims can also be proved independently of that contract.Â  Being called â€œdishonestâ€ 
  to oneâ€™s supervisor, co-workers, and relatives, harassed by repeated phone calls, 
  and subjected to intentional infliction of emotional distress, as alleged in 
  the complaint, constitutes tortious behavior that the parties, it seems to us, 
  could not have reasonably foreseen and for which we seriously doubt they intended 
  to provide a limited means of redress. 
  [16] Â  
Based on the foregoing, we agree with the circuit courtâ€™s finding that â€œ[t]he 
  complaint is based upon tortious conduct of the employees of [Global-Sun Pools] 
  unrelated to the contractâ€ and â€œthe allegations of the complaint do not arise 
  out of nor do they relate to the contract[.]â€Â  The circuit court, therefore, 
  did not err in denying the motion to compel arbitration.
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., and WILLIAMS, J., concur.

 
   [1] Â  This statute makes it a misdemeanor to use a telephone to 
    make harassing, intimidating, threatening, or obscene phone calls.Â  No issue 
    is before us as to whether this statute creates a private right of action.Â  
    See, e.g., Whitlaw v. Kroger Co., 306 S.C. 51, 55, 410 S.E.2d 
    251, 253 (1991) (holding statutory prohibitions on selling alcohol to a person 
    under the age of twenty-one create a private right of action if the plaintiff 
    can establish negligence per se and â€œthat violation of the statute[s] was 
    causally linked, both in fact and proximately, to the injuryâ€).

 
   [2]  Â Zabinski v. Bright Acres Assocs., 346 
    S.C. 580, 553 S.E.2d 110 (2001).

 
   [3] Â  Thorton v. Trident Med. Ctr., 357 S.C. 
    91, 592 S.E.2d 50 (Ct. App. 2003); Rich v. Walsh, 357 S.C. 64, 590 
    S.E.2d 506 (Ct. App. 2003).

 
    [4] Â  Zabinski, 346 S.C. at 596, 553 S.E.2d 
    at 118.

 
   [5] Â  Id. at 596-97, 553 S.E.2d at 118.Â Â  

 
   [6]  Â South Carolina Pub. Serv. Auth. v. Great W. 
    Coal (Ky.), Inc., 312 S.C. 559, 563, 437 S.E.2d 22, 25 (1993).

 
   [7] Â  Id. at 564, 437 S.E.2d at 25.

 
   [8] Â  The financing statement also references an arbitration clause, 
    but it was not relied upon in the circuit courtâ€™s order.

 
   [9]  Vestry and Church Wardens of Church of Holy 
    Cross v. Orkin Exterminating Co., 356 S.C. 202, 209, 588 S.E.2d 136, 140 
    (Ct. App. 2003), cert. denied, (S.C. Oct. 6, 2004).

 
    [10] Â  Id.

 
   [11] Â  Id. at 210, 588 S.E.2d at 140.

 
    [12] Â  Id.

 
   [13]  Â Zabinski, 346 S.C. at 598, 553 S.E.2d 
    at 119.

 
   [14] Â  Id. at 597 n.4, 553 S.E.2d at 119 n.4.

 
   [15] Â  We note that the arbitration provision in this 
    case specifies that arbitration is the exclusive remedy for matters whether 
    â€œwarranty, contract, negligence or strict liabilityâ€ and it limits 
    any remedy to repair of the defect.Â  [Emphasis added.]Â  Negligence, while 
    itself a tort, does not encompass all torts, particularly intentional torts 
    such as defamation and intentional infliction of emotional distress alleged 
    by Chassereau.Â  Moreover, as noted above, unlawful use of a telephone is a 
    misdemeanor.

 
   
    [16] Â  Fuller v. Guthrie, 565 F.2d 259 (2d Cir. 1977).Â  Fuller 
    involved an action brought by a concert promoter against a performer and others 
    to recover damages for breach of contract and, as here, slander.Â  The arbitration 
    clause in the performerâ€™s contract â€œprovide[d] that â€˜the parties will submit 
    every claim, dispute, controversy, or difference involving the musical services 
    arising out of or connected withâ€™ the contract toâ€ arbitration.Â  Id. 
    at 260.Â  The United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit found this 
    clause did not require arbitration of the slander claim because â€œthe agreement 
    to arbitrate was undoubtedly intended to cover disputes arising from the character 
    of Guthrieâ€™s performance and his payment for it, [but] it is highly unlikely 
    that the parties could have foreseen, no less intended, to provide a forum 
    for wholly unexpected tortious behavior.â€Â  Id. at 261 (emphasis 
    added).

title: State v. Carlson
description: In this criminal appeal, the appellant alleges the Trial Court erred in: (1)	Not following the appropriate procedure in allowing the victim to identify the defendant in court; (2)	Allowing the enlarged photo of Richard Carlson to be admitted into evidence; (3)	Not re-reading all testimony of the victim as was requested by the jury; (4)	Improperly communicating with jurors while deliberations were ongoing; (5)	Allowing the Solicitorâ€™s office to engage in an improper closing argument; (6)	Failing to find a Brady v. Maryland violation; (7)	Allowing cross-examination of Heather Wilson through a written statement; and (8)	Telling Appellant Carlson any criminal conviction would be admissible if he took the stand.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
The State, Respondent,
v.
Russell Carl Carlson, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Georgetown County
Â J. Michael Baxley, Circuit Court 
  Judge

Opinion No. 3948
Heard February 9, 2005 â€“ Filed February 
  22, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Gene McCain Connell, Jr., of Surfside Beach, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy 
  Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley 
  W. Elliott, and Assistant Attorney General David A. Spencer, Office of the Attorney 
  General, all of Columbia; and Solicitor John Gregory Hembree, of Conway, for 
  Respondent.
      
    
  

ANDERSON, J.: Russell Carl Carlson appeals his convictions for assault 
  and battery with intent to kill and first degree burglary.Â  We affirm. 
  [1] 
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
Junior DeWitt lived 
  with his fiancÃ©e, Stephanie Davis, and her two children.Â  One morning, as Davisâ€™s 
  daughter was getting ready for school, two men entered DeWittâ€™s home wearing 
  all black and carrying guns.Â  DeWitt was in bed asleep when he was awakened 
  by the sound of the door being kicked open, glass breaking, and gunshots.Â  One 
  of the intruders was a man with several gold teeth who was wearing a bandana.Â  
  He was carrying guns in both hands and shot DeWitt multiple times as DeWitt 
  stumbled out of bed.Â  The intruders rifled through DeWittâ€™s clothes, took approximately 
  $500, and then left.Â  DeWitt sustained severe injuries.Â  He was in a coma for 
  a month and is now paralyzed; he will never walk again.Â Â  
DeWitt recognized Carlson 
  as the shooter and identified Demar â€œDemondâ€ Moore as the other intruder.Â  DeWitt 
  had known Moore for approximately ten years before the incident.Â  He recognized 
  Carlson because Carlson and Moore had come to his house a couple of weeks before 
  the shooting, and the three had engaged in conversation for around fifteen to 
  twenty minutes.Â  
Moore and Carlson were 
  tried together.Â  The jury convicted Carlson of assault and battery with intent 
  to kill, and burglary in the first degree, and sentenced him to twenty years 
  in prison.Â  Carlson raises eight issues on appeal.Â  Due to the number of issues, 
  and for the sake of clarity, we set forth the remaining facts necessary for 
  our decision in the discussion of the issues to which they pertain.Â  See 
  Hundley v. Rite Aid of South Carolina, Inc., 339 S.C. 285, 293, 529 S.E.2d 
  45, 49 (Ct. App. 2000). 
LAW/ANALYSIS
I. In-Court Identification
During the investigation police showed DeWitt a photo lineup.Â  
  DeWitt picked out Carlson without hesitation.Â  However, the picture of Carlson 
  was approximately four to five times larger than the other photos.Â  The trial 
  judge decided to exclude the lineup, finding it unduly suggestive.Â  Although 
  the prior identification was not admitted, the trial judge did allow DeWitt 
  to identify Carlson in court.Â  The judge found DeWitt could make a reliable 
  in-court identification of Carlson based on factors independent of the improperly 
  suggestive lineup.Â  
Carlson first argues the trial court failed to conduct a 
  proper hearing on the admissibility of DeWittâ€™s out-of-court identification 
  pursuant to Neil v. Biggers, 409 U.S. 188 (1972) and State v. Ramsey, 
  345 S.C. 607, 550 S.E.2d 294 (2001).Â  Generally, a trial court must hold an 
  in camera hearing when the State offers a witness whose testimony identifies 
  the defendant as the person who committed the crime, and the defendant challenges 
  the in-court identification as being tainted by a previous, illegal identification 
  or confrontation.Â  Ramsey at 613, 550 S.E.2d at 297 (citing State 
  v. Cash, 257 S.C. 249, 185 S.E.2d 525 (1971)); State v. Cheatham, 
  349 S.C. 101, 561 S.E.2d 618 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  The purpose of the in camera 
  hearing is to determine whether the in-court identification was of independent 
  origin or was the tainted product of the circumstances surrounding the prior, 
  out-of-court identification.Â Â  See Ramsey at 613, 550 S.E.2d at 
  297.Â  
Defense counsel did not object to the procedure used in the 
  present case.Â  During pretrial motions, the trial judge suggested that the court 
  merely view the pictures rather than require testimony.Â  Counsel for Carlson 
  responded: â€œNo objection, Your Honor.â€Â  
Â â€œAn issue may not be raised for the first time on appeal, 
  but must have been raised to the trial judge to be preserved for appellate review.â€Â  
  State v. Nichols, 325 S.C. 111, 120-21, 481 S.E.2d 118, 123 (1997) (citation 
  omitted); accord State v. Fleming, 254 S.C. 415, 175 S.E.2d 624 
  (1970); State v. Adams, 354 S.C. 361, 580 S.E.2d 785 (Ct. App. 2003), 
  cert. denied.Â  A party cannot complain of an error which his own conduct 
  has induced.Â  State v. Stroman, 281 S.C. 508, 513, 316 S.E.2d 395, 399 
  (1984).Â  â€œWhere an objection and the ground therefore is not stated in the record, 
  there is no basis for appellate review.â€Â  State v. Morris, 307 S.C. 480, 
  485, 415 S.E.2d 819, 823 (Ct. App. 1991).Â  A contemporaneous objection is required 
  to preserve issues for direct appellate review.Â  State v. King, 334 S.C. 
  504, 514 S.E.2d 578 (1999); State v. Thomason, 355 S.C. 278, 584 S.E.2d 
  143 (Ct. App. 2003); State v. Greene, 330 S.C. 551, 499 S.E.2d 817 (Ct. 
  App. 1997).Â  Cf. State v. McCrary, 242 S.C. 506, 131 S.E.2d 687 
  (1963) (opining the court was without authority to consider question on appeal 
  where defendant consented to being tried on two indictments at same time and 
  raised no objection to such mode of trial in trial court).
Not only did Carlson fail to object, but he consented 
  to the procedure proposed by the trial judge.Â  Consequently, Carlson failed 
  to preserve this issue.
At oral argument, Carlsonâ€™s appellate counsel contended 
  that the right to a hearing was a constitutional due process issue and could 
  not be waived.Â  We disagree.Â  A plethora of cases from the appellate entities 
  of this state recognize that constitutional rights may be waived.Â  For example, 
  in Burnett v. State, 352 S.C. 589, 591, 576 S.E.2d 144, 145 (2003), our 
  supreme court observed that â€œ[e]ntering a guilty plea results in a waiver of 
  several constitutional rights . . . .â€Â  In State v. Varvil, 338 S.C. 
  335, 526 S.E.2d 248 (Ct. App. 2000), this Court held that the appellant waived 
  his First Amendment right to free speech by failing to preserve the issue for 
  review.Â  We noted that constitutional arguments are no exception to the error 
  preservation rule, â€œand if not raised to the trial court are deemed waived on 
  appeal.â€Â  Id. at 339, 526 S.E.2d at 250.Â  See also State v. 
  Downs, 361 S.C. 141, 604 S.E.2d 377 (2004) (acknowledging a defendant may 
  waive the right to a trial by jury on both guilt and sentencing); State v. 
  Owens, 346 S.C. 637, 552 S.E.2d 745 (2001) (providing the Fifth Amendment 
  privilege against self-incrimination may be waived); Brown v. State, 
  340 S.C. 590, 533 S.E.2d 308 (2000) (same); State v. Shuler, 344 S.C. 
  604, 545 S.E.2d 805 (2001) (recognizing the Sixth Amendment right to confrontation 
  may be waived); State v. Thompson, 355 S.C. 255, 584 S.E.2d 131 (Ct. 
  App. 2003) (explaining the waiver of the Sixth Amendment right to counsel and 
  comparing waiver by affirmative, verbal request with waiver by conduct).
In the case sub judice, consent was given 
  and constituted waiver of any procedural due process rights.Â  
II. Use of Photograph at Trial
Carlson asserts the trial court erred in allowing a photograph of Carlson to 
  be admitted into evidence.Â  We disagree.
The trial judge did not allow the State to use DeWittâ€™s identification of Carlson 
  from the photographic lineup because the judge found the disproportionality 
  of Carlsonâ€™s picture vis-Ã -vis the other photos rendered the lineup inappropriately 
  suggestive.Â  Carlson argues â€œit was error to allow the same photograph or a 
  similar photograph into evidence when the court had held the photographs inadmissible 
  as being too suggestive from the photo lineup shown to the victim.â€Â  He explains:Â  
  â€œIt seems logical that the court should not allow the admission of a photo into 
  evidence after the court has found that the same photo was too suggestive to 
  be used as part of the photo lineup.â€Â  
Initially, we note there are two photographs of Carlson in 
  the record.Â  The first picture was taken within a month following the shooting.Â  
  This photo depicts Carlson with his mouth closed and is not marked as an exhibit.Â  
  The second photograph was taken approximately a year after the shooting, while 
  Carlson was in jail.Â  In the second picture, Carlson has his mouth open, his 
  gold teeth prominently displayed.Â  This picture is marked â€œStateâ€™s Exhibit 29.â€Â  

We find the record clearly establishes that the second photographâ€”which 
  was not utilized in the pretrial lineupâ€”is the photo that was entered into evidence 
  and shown to the jury.Â  In arguing Carlsonâ€™s motion to suppress the pretrial 
  photo lineup as unduly suggestive, the State mentioned that DeWitt could make 
  an independently reliable in-court identification of Carlson because DeWitt 
  observed the shooter had gold teeth, and in the picture used in the lineup, 
  Carlsonâ€™s mouth was closed, so his teeth were not visible.Â  
Additionally, counsel for Carlson objected to the admission 
  of Stateâ€™s Exhibit 29 on the ground that it might not be an accurate depiction 
  of Carlson at the time the shooting occurred, because it was taken about a year 
  after the attack.Â  The picture taken a year after the crime cannot be the same 
  photograph utilized in the lineup viewed approximately one month after the attack.Â  
  Thus, by counselâ€™s own admission, the photo entered into evidence was not the 
  photograph employed in the pretrial lineup. 
Further, the preservation of this issue is dubious.Â  A defendant 
  must object to an in-court identification to properly preserve the issue for 
  appeal.Â  See State v. Wakefield, 323 S.C. 189, 196, 473 S.E.2d 
  831, 835 (Ct. App. 1996) (â€œWakefield was required to object to the in-court 
  identification at trial to properly preserve this issue for appeal.â€).Â  Arguments 
  not raised to or ruled upon by the trial court are not preserved for appellate 
  review.Â  State v. Wise, 359 S.C. 14, 596 S.E.2d 475 (2004), cert. 
  denied; State v. Perez, 334 S.C. 563, 514 S.E.2d 754 (1999).Â  â€œA 
  defendant may not argue one ground below and another on appeal.â€Â  State v. 
  Adams, 354 S.C. 361, 380, 580 S.E.2d 785, 795 (Ct. App. 2003), cert. 
  denied; see also State v. Dunbar, 356 S.C. 138, 587 S.E.2d 
  691 (2003) (â€œA party may not argue one ground at trial and an alternate ground 
  on appeal.â€); accord State v. Prioleau, 345 S.C. 404, 548 S.E.2d 
  213 (2001).Â  Carlson noted he â€œwould certainly vehemently oppose the introduction 
  of the evidence,â€ and cited the justification that the photograph was â€œtaken 
  . . a year after he was in jail,â€ and therefore did not â€œrepresent his appearance 
  at the time of the crime.â€Â  Now, on appeal, Carlson contends the photograph 
  was unduly suggestive and violates Biggers and Ramsey.Â  This constitutional 
  argument was not the basis of the objection at trial.Â  
Nevertheless, we do not find Neil v. Biggers, 409 U.S. 188 (1972), or 
  State v. Ramsey, 345 S.C. 607, 550 S.E.2d 294 (2001), controlling.Â  Biggers 
  addressed whether a showup identification was so suggestive that it violated 
  the defendantâ€™s right to due process.Â  The victim in Biggers viewed several 
  suspects in both lineups and showups, and was shown thirty or forty photographs, 
  but was unable to identify her attacker.Â  The police called her in to view a 
  suspect who was being detained on another charge.Â  Officers attempted to construct 
  a lineup, but were unable to find anyone at the city jail or city juvenile home 
  matching the defendantâ€™s description.Â  Thus, they conducted a showup instead, 
  and the victim identified the defendant as the perpetrator.Â Â  Under the totality 
  of the circumstances, the identification was reliable even though the confrontation 
  procedure was suggestive.Â  Biggers at 199-201.Â  The Supreme Court found 
  â€œno substantial likelihood of misidentification.â€Â  Id. at 201.
In State v. Ramsey, a distinctive sweater was found 
  near a murdered body.Â  Several witnesses testified to seeing the defendant wearing 
  the sweater on the day of the murder.Â  Two of the witnesses were police officers 
  who had seen an individual wearing the sweater outside the county courthouse 
  several days before the homicide.Â  The officers identified the defendant from 
  a photo lineup.Â  On appeal, the defendant argued the trial judge erred by refusing 
  to hold an in camera hearing to challenge the identification procedure.Â  
  The court noted that the defendant in Ramsey cited cases â€œinvolving situations 
  where an in-court identification [was] the product of an unlawful confrontation 
  or lineup.â€Â  345 S.C. at 613, 550 S.E.2d at 297.Â  The court held those cases 
  were â€œimmaterial because the issue in this case is simply whether an out-of-court 
  photographic lineup was impermissibly suggestive, not whether the subsequent 
  in-court identification was tainted.â€Â  Id.Â  In the case sub judice, 
  the trial judge found the out-of-court photographic lineup was impermissibly 
  suggestive; therefore, he did not allow evidence of the pretrial identification.Â  
  Ramsey is inapposite to the facts in this case.
Further, we disagree with Carlson that â€œ[i]t seems logical that the court should 
  not allow the admission of a photo into evidence after the court has found that 
  the same photo was too suggestive to be used as part of the photo lineup.â€Â  
  First, Carlsonâ€™s assertion is factually erroneous because the photograph admitted 
  into evidence was not the same picture used in the lineup.Â  Second, the trial 
  judge found the photo lineup procedure suggestive because Carlsonâ€™s picture 
  was four or five times larger than the other photos; in other words, the procedureâ€™s 
  suggestiveness emanated from the discrepancy between the sizes of the picturesâ€”not 
  Carlsonâ€™s picture itself.Â  It does not follow that because a picture stands 
  out from a group it is thereby unduly suggestive in isolation.Â  We reject Carlsonâ€™s 
  argument that the picture should not have been entered into evidence.Â  The admission 
  of Stateâ€™s Exhibit 29 in no way introduced evidence of the suggestive pretrial 
  identification.Â  The picture is relevant because it prominently shows Carlsonâ€™s 
  gold teeth, a distinctive feature that was significant in DeWittâ€™s description 
  of his assailant.Â  
Finally, we find the in-court identification was proper.Â  
  Criminal defendants are constitutionally protected from identification procedures 
  that are so unnecessarily suggestive and conducive to irreparable mistaken identification 
  as to deprive them of due process of law.Â  Manson v. Brathwaite, 432 
  U.S. 98 (1977); Stovall v. Denno, 388 U.S. 293, 301-02 (1967), overruled 
  on other grounds by Griffith v. Kentucky, 479 U.S. 314 (1987).Â  The 
  determination is to be made based on the totality of the circumstances.Â  Stovall 
  at 301-02; see also State v. Patterson, 337 S.C. 215, 229, 522 
  S.E.2d 845, 852 (Ct. App. 1999) (â€œThe query posited is whether under the totality 
  of the circumstances the identification was reliable even though the confrontation 
  procedure may have been suggestive.â€) (internal quotation marks and citation 
  omitted).Â  
Because the trial judge in the instant case did not allow 
  the out-of-court photographic lineup into evidence, the issue here is DeWittâ€™s 
  in-court identification of Carlson.Â  A conviction based on a suggestive pretrial 
  photographic lineup and a subsequent in-court identification will be set aside 
  only if â€œthe photographic identification procedure was so impermissibly suggestive 
  as to give rise to a very substantial likelihood of irreparable misidentification.â€Â  
  Simmons v. United States, 390 U.S. 377, 384 (1968); accord State 
  v. Moore, 343 S.C. 282, 286, 540 S.E.2d 445, 447 (2000) (â€œAn in-court identification 
  of an accused is inadmissible if a suggestive out-of-court identification procedure 
  created a very substantial likelihood of irreparable misidentification.â€); State 
  v. Tisdale, 338 S.C. 607, 611, 527 S.E.2d 389, 392 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  The 
  in-court identification is admissible if based on information independent of 
  the out-of-court procedure.Â  State v. Rogers, 263 S.C. 373, 210 S.E.2d 
  604 (1974).Â  The State bears the burden of proving that the identification was 
  based on an independent source by clear and convincing evidence.Â  Id. 
  at 377, 210 S.E.2d at 606.Â  
The record contains ample evidence supporting the reliability 
  and independence of DeWittâ€™s identification of Carlson.Â  DeWitt talked to Moore 
  and Carlson for fifteen to twenty minutes about two weeks before the shooting 
  took place.Â  During that time, Carlson was standing approximately a foot away 
  from DeWitt, directly in front of him.Â  When the shooting occurred, DeWitt was 
  two to three feet from Carlson.Â  The light in the room was shining brightly.Â  
  DeWitt recognized Carlson because he could see through the sheer bandana Carlson 
  was wearing.Â  DeWitt recalled seeing Carlsonâ€™s gold teeth, â€œthe same teeth I 
  seen him that same day when he came with Demond Moore to the house.â€Â  DeWitt 
  testified that he had a clear view of Carlson throughout the shooting.Â  
When DeWitt awoke from the coma approximately one month later, 
  he was presented with the photo lineup.Â  DeWitt picked out Carlson without hesitation, 
  saying that he was one hundred percent certain of Carlsonâ€™s identity.Â  At trial, 
  DeWitt again asserted with certitude that Carlson was the attacker.Â  
Thus, DeWitt had an opportunity to view Carlson closely both 
  before and during the time the shooting occurred, with an elevated degree of 
  attention.Â  He demonstrated a high level of certainty as to the accuracy of 
  the identification, and the identification was made as soon as possible after 
  the incident occurred.Â  There was no likelihood of misidentification. 
Therefore, use of the Stateâ€™s Exhibit 29 at trial was not 
  improper.Â  The photograph from the lineup was never admitted into evidence, 
  and Carlson did not make a specific objection.Â  The identification was sufficiently 
  reliable to make the probability of misidentification insubstantial. 
III. Replay of Testimony During Jury Deliberations
Carlson next challenges the trial judgeâ€™s decision not to 
  require the jury to review DeWittâ€™s entire testimony.Â  We affirm. 
During deliberations, the jury requested to rehear DeWittâ€™s 
  testimony.Â  The trial judge granted the request.Â  The poor sound quality, however, 
  required the court reporter to read the solicitorâ€™s questions before replaying 
  the answers.Â  When dinner arrived, the trial judge recessed the reading and 
  stated: â€œWeâ€™ll come back and conclude this at that time after you finish, all 
  right?â€Â  The jury sent an oral message to the court through the bailiff that 
  it would consider whether to hear the remainder of the testimony after the break.Â  
  The jury never requested to hear the remaining testimony.Â  
After the verdict was returned, counsel for Moore moved for 
  a new trial, arguing that only a portion of the direct examination of DeWitt 
  had been replayed, and none of the cross-examination.Â  Counsel for Carlson joined 
  the motion.Â  The trial judge denied the motion, noting that the playback had 
  been â€œa laborious and cumbersome procedure,â€ and finding the decision not to 
  continue it was within the juryâ€™s discretion.Â  
Â â€œThe trial judge, in his discretion, may permit the jury 
  at their request to review, in the defendantâ€™s presence, testimony after the 
  beginning of deliberations.â€Â  State v. Plyler, 275 S.C. 291, 298, 270 
  S.E.2d 126, 129 (1980).Â  The extent of the review is within the trial judgeâ€™s 
  discretion, which is to be exercised in the light of the juryâ€™s request.Â  Id.Â  

The facts of the case sub judice are similar to those 
  in Plyler, where the jury requested the testimony of a key witness be 
  read back to them.Â  There, â€œ[t]he tape was replayed, and upon the conclusion 
  of the direct testimony, the foreman informed the court that the jury had heard 
  all they desired.Â  The tape was stopped and the jury returned to their deliberations.â€Â  
  Id. at 298, 270 S.E.2d at 129.Â  The defendantâ€™s motion that the jury 
  be required to hear the cross-examination was denied by the trial judge.Â  Our 
  supreme court affirmed, holding: â€œThe court is not required to submit evidence 
  to the jury for review beyond that specifically requested but may, in its discretion, 
  have the jury review other evidence relating to the same factual issue so as 
  not to give undue prominence to the evidence requested.â€Â  Id.
Similarly, in State v. Summer, 276 S.C. 11, 274 S.E.2d 
  427 (1981), overruled on other grounds by State v. McFadden, 342 
  S.C. 629, 539 S.E.2d 387 (2000), the jury requested to hear both the direct 
  and cross-examinations of the victim and a doctor.Â  Apparently, only the direct 
  examinations were played.Â  When the jury returned to its deliberations, defense 
  counsel objected to the court â€œâ€˜not allowing the jury to listen to the cross-examination 
  of the prosecuting witness in the same area of testimony that the jury listened 
  to of the direct examination.â€™â€Â  Id. at 16, 274 S.E.2d at 430.Â  The court, 
  citing Plyler, emphasized â€œthe broad discretion vested in the trial judge 
  in dealing with requests of the jury to review evidence during their deliberations.â€Â  
  Id.Â  The court explicated: â€œWhile the record fails to show what testimony 
  was reproduced for the jury, it is reasonably inferable that the jury was satisfied 
  with the courtâ€™s response to their requests and indicated no further need for 
  a review of the testimony.â€Â  Id.Â  In view of the appellantâ€™s failure 
  to â€œclearly show a failure of the court to comply with the request of the jury 
  and the inference that the jury apparently felt their request had been met,â€ 
  the court found â€œno abuse of discretion.â€Â  Id.Â  See also State 
  v. Lincoln, 213 S.C. 553, 50 S.E.2d 687 (1948), overruled on other grounds 
  by State v. Torrence, 305 S.C. 45, 406 S.E.2d 315 (1991).Â  The rule 
  in federal courts is similar.Â  U.S. v. Holmes, 863 F.2d 4, 5 (2nd Cir. 
  1988). 
We find no abuse of discretion in the trial judgeâ€™s actions.Â  
  The law imposes no duty on the judge to require the jury to hear additional 
  testimony.Â  Plyler, 275 S.C. at 298, 270 S.E.2d at 129.Â  
Additionally, the preservation of this issue is questionable 
  since no objection was made until after the verdict was returned.Â  In order 
  to preserve this issue, Carlson must have made a request at trial to have the 
  remainder of the testimony replayed.Â  State v. Hartley, 307 S.C. 239, 
  414 S.E.2d 182 (Ct. App. 1992).Â  Carlson made such a request, but it was not 
  contemporaneous.Â  In Hartley, the jury â€œasked to hear replayed only the 
  solicitorâ€™s cross-examination of Hartley.â€Â  Id. at 243, 414 S.E.2d at 
  185.Â  This Court held that â€œ[w]e need not address Hartleyâ€™s complaint concerning 
  the failure of the trial judge to require the jury . . . to listen to other 
  portions of [Hartleyâ€™s] testimony . . . .â€Â  Id. at 244, 414 S.E.2d at 
  185.Â  We expounded: â€œHartley never asked the trial judge to have the â€˜other 
  portionsâ€™ of Hartleyâ€™s testimony . . . played back to the jury.Â  Moreover, he 
  never objected at trial to the playback of only Hartleyâ€™s cross-examination 
  by the solicitor.â€Â  Id.Â  We concluded that, even if we were to reach 
  the issue, â€œwe would hold the trial judge committed no abuse of discretion.â€Â  
  Id. (citing Plyler, 275 S.C. at 298, 270 S.E.2d at 129).Â  See 
  also State v. Curtis, 356 S.C. 622, 633, 591 S.E.2d 600, 605 (2004) 
  (holding that an objection made after several pages of testimony came too late 
  to preserve the issue); State v. King, 334 S.C. 504, 510, 514 S.E.2d 
  578, 581 (1999) (concluding that appellant waived review by failing to object 
  before the jury verdict); State v. Hoffman, 312 S.C. 386, 393, 440 S.E.2d 
  869, 873 (1994) (holding that a contemporaneous objection is required to preserve 
  an issue for appellate review). 
IV. Interaction Between Jury and Bailiff
Carlson contends he should be granted a new trial because 
  the bailiff allegedly engaged in an improper discussion with the jury during 
  deliberations.Â  The record indicates that during the dinner break the jury sent 
  an oral message to the court through the bailiff that it would consider whether 
  it wished to hear the remainder of the testimony.Â  Defense counsel moved for 
  a new trial, and the trial judge denied the motion, explaining:

As to the hearing the entire testimony of the witness, Mr. 
  DeWitt, I will say this to you and you may not be aware of it, it would have 
  occurred off the record, but when dinner concluded last night the foreperson 
  of the jury informed the bailiff who was removing the trash and other cups and 
  things of that nature from the room that the jury was going to first consider 
  whether they wished to hear any further testimony, and we never heard back from 
  the jury again.Â  The implication to the Court, of course, being that they didnâ€™t 
  care to hear any more testimony.Â  That was a laborious and cumbersome procedure, 
  most difficult for our court reporter and one that was difficult for those listening, 
  and I certainly can understand why the jury would not have wanted to continue 
  listening to the testimony.Â  I find no error in that, sir.Â  In fact, I find 
  that to have been within the discretion of the jury and they exercised their 
  discretion and thatâ€™s appropriate. 

Carlson argues this to be a violation of the sanctity of 
  the jury system, entitling him to a new trial.Â  Carlson relies on State v. 
  Cameron, 311 S.C. 204, 428 S.E.2d 10 (Ct. App. 1993), wherein the court 
  remarked: â€œthere was the private communication of the court official to members 
  of the jury, an occurrence which cannot be tolerated if the sanctity of the 
  jury system is to be maintained.â€Â  Id. at 208, 428 S.E.2d at 12.Â  In 
  Cameron, the defendant was accused of entering a bank with intent to 
  steal.Â  The trial judge charged the jury that if it found the defendant guilty 
  it would have to decide whether or not to recommend mercy.Â  If the jury decided 
  not to recommend mercy, the defendant would be given a life sentence.Â  The jury 
  returned a verdict of guilty without a recommendation of mercy.Â  However, after 
  the verdict, the trial judge discovered that the bailiff had a discussion with 
  the forelady of the jury during deliberations.Â  When the forelady informed the 
  bailiff that the jury â€œwanted a description about if they went with the sentence 
  of mercy that he wouldnâ€™t make it life,â€ the bailiff responded, â€œ . . . donâ€™t 
  worry about it the Judge is fair.â€Â  Id. at 206-07, 428 S.E.2d at 11.
The trial judge refused to declare a mistrial, but a divided 
  court of appeals reversed.Â  We held that when a court official engaged in private 
  communication with the jury, â€œâ€˜a new trial must be granted unless it clearly 
  appears that the subject matter of the communication was harmless and could 
  not have affected the verdict.â€™â€Â  Id. at 207-08, 428 S.E.2d at 12 (quoting 
  Holmes v. United States, 284 F.2d 716, 718 (4th Cir. 1960)).Â  Yet, we 
  observed, â€œThe mere fact . . . that some conversation occurred between a juror 
  and the court official would not necessarily prejudice a defendant.â€Â  Cameron 
  at 207-08, 428 S.E.2d at 12. 
In this case, there was no communication by the bailiff to 
  the jury.Â  The bailiff simply relayed the message without responding.Â  Nor was 
  there any indication of improper outside influences.Â  Cameron deals only 
  with â€œprivate communications of the court official to members of the juryâ€ and 
  is thus inapplicable.Â  Id.Â  
Our supreme court has outlined the proper procedure for this 
  situation:Â  

If, during deliberation, the jury finds need to review portions 
  of the testimony or to consult the court regarding questions of law, the foreman 
  should inform the bailiff that the jury wishes to consult with the judge.Â  The 
  subject matter of the juryâ€™s inquiry should not be discussed at all.Â  The bailiffâ€™s 
  single responsibility is to advise the court of the foremanâ€™s request.Â  The 
  matter is then completely in the hands of the trial judge. 

Jacobs v. Am. Mut. Fire Ins. Co. of Charleston, 287 
  S.C. 541, 543, 340 S.E.2d 142, 143 (1986). 
We find no error here.Â  The bailiff did exactly what he should 
  have doneâ€”he advised the trial judge of the juryâ€™s communication without commenting 
  on the subject matter of the case.Â  Furthermore, defense counsel made no objection 
  on this ground at trial.Â  Nor was any request made to have the bailiff or jurors 
  examined to determine if any prejudicial exchange occurred. 
V. Closing Remarks
Carlsonâ€™s next ground for appeal deals with the following 
  remarks made by the prosecutor during closing arguments:

Now, the Defense made a big deal about, you know, â€œDonâ€™t 
  get carried away with the brutality of it.Â  Weâ€™re not saying itâ€™s not brutal.Â  
  Weâ€™re so sorry this happened,â€ which Iâ€™ll submit to you I didnâ€™tâ€”these Defendants 
  have the right not to testify, and they can, you know, we have the burden of 
  proof and theyâ€™ve got a constitutional right not to testify but they canâ€™t come 
  in and apologize.

Counsel for Moore immediately objected.Â  The trial judge 
  sustained the objection and gave a curative instruction: â€œThereâ€™s no inference 
  to be taken.Â  The Defendants have a right to remain silent and have a right 
  not to testify.â€Â  The judge charged the jury that defendants have a constitutional 
  right not to testify, and that their failure to testify could not be used against 
  them, even to the slightest degree.Â  Defense counsel did not make any further 
  motions. 
Once again, this issue has not been preserved for review.Â  
  â€œFailure to object to comments made during argument precludes appellate review 
  of the issue.â€Â  State v. Varvil, 338 S.C. 335, 339, 526 S.E.2d 248, 251 
  (Ct. App. 2000).Â  In the instant case, counsel for Moore objected, but Carlson 
  did not.Â  In State v. Carriker, 269 S.C. 553, 238 S.E.2d 678 (1977), 
  the court held appellantâ€™s assertion of error was not preserved because â€œappellantâ€™s 
  counsel made no objection . . . at trial.Â  While appellantâ€™s co-defendant did 
  object, the appellant may not utilize the objection of another defendant to 
  gain review.â€Â  Id. at 555, 238 S.E.2d at 678; see also State 
  v. Brannon, 347 S.C. 85, 89, 552 S.E.2d 773, 775 (Ct. App. 2001) (finding 
  failure to suppress evidence not preserved where appellant did not join in co-defendantâ€™s 
  motion to suppress); State v. Nichols, 325 S.C. 111, 123, 481 S.E.2d 
  118, 124 (1997) (â€œFinally, the remaining issues raised by appellant are not 
  preserved for review since appellant failed to object during trial or join in 
  his co-defendantâ€™s objections.â€).Â  Because Carlson did not raise an objection 
  to the solicitorâ€™s comments and did not join in his co-defendantâ€™s objection, 
  this issue is not preserved.
Additionally, neither party moved to strike or requested 
  a curative instruction.Â  See State v. Patterson, 324 S.C. 5, 18, 
  482 S.E.2d 760, 766 (1997) (holding that where an appellant objects to improper 
  comments in closing arguments and the objection is sustained, the issue is not 
  preserved unless the appellant further moves to strike or requests a curative 
  instruction); State v. Primus, 341 S.C. 592, 604, 535 S.E.2d 152, 158 
  (Ct. App. 2000), (providing a thorough discussion and concluding â€œthe cases 
  are legion in holding that if an appellant objects and the objection is sustained 
  but he does not move for a curative instruction or request a mistrial he has 
  received what he asked for and cannot be heard to complain on appeal.â€), revâ€™d 
  in part on other grounds, 349 S.C. 576, 564 S.E.2d 103 (2002); State 
  v. McFadden, 318 S.C. 404, 410, 458 S.E.2d 61, 65 (Ct. App. 1995) (noting 
  that appellant must move to strike to preserve issue for appeal). 
Even if the issue were properly preserved, there would be 
  no reversible error.Â  Improper closing argument does not automatically require 
  reversal of a conviction.Â  State v. Huggins, 325 S.C. 103, 481 S.E.2d 
  114 (1997); State v. Copeland, 321 S.C. 318, 468 S.E.2d 620 (1996).Â  
  â€œIt is impermissible for the prosecution to comment, directly or indirectly, 
  upon the defendantâ€™s failure to testify at trial.â€Â  State v. Cooper, 
  334 S.C. 540, 544, 514 S.E.2d 584, 591 (1999).Â  â€œHowever, improper comments 
  on a defendantâ€™s failure to testify do not automatically require reversal if 
  they are not prejudicial to the defendant.â€Â  Id.Â  The appropriateness 
  of a solicitorâ€™s closing argument and the decision whether to grant a defendantâ€™s 
  motion for a mistrial are matters within the trial judgeâ€™s discretion that ordinarily 
  will not be disturbed on appeal.Â  State v. Sweet, 342 S.C. 342, 347, 
  536 S.E.2d 91, 93 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  
Negative inferences created by prosecutors can be cured if 
  the trial judge gives an immediate curative instruction to the jury.Â  Cooper, 
  334 S.C. at 554, 514 S.E.2d at 591.Â  If the trial judge charges the jury during 
  jury instructions that the burden of proof is fully on the State, and that the 
  jury may not consider a defendantâ€™s failure to testify in its deliberations, 
  any prejudicial effect can be cured.Â  Id.Â  The appellant has the burden 
  of proving he did not receive a fair trial because of the improper argument.Â  
  State v. Linder, 276 S.C. 304, 278 S.E.2d 335 (1981).Â  Because the trial 
  judge gave an immediate curative instruction upon objection of defense counsel, 
  and charged the jury that failure to testify could not be used against either 
  defendant, any prejudicial effect was cured.Â  
VI. Brady Claim
Carlson contends the prosecution violated his rights under 
  Brady v. Maryland, 373 U.S. 83 (1963), by failing to provide a forty-page 
  transcript to defense counsel prior to trial.Â  During cross-examination of Carlsonâ€™s 
  alibi witness, Heather Wilson, the prosecution used a transcribed conversation 
  between Wilson and an investigator to impeach her.Â  Counsel for Moore objected 
  on the ground that he had not been provided a copy.Â  The trial judge required 
  the State to provide the transcript to the defense.Â  Counsel for Moore further 
  objected that he had not had time to review the document.Â  The trial judge allowed 
  cross-examination to continue, but announced that he would permit defense counsel 
  to recall the witness after a recess.Â  Moore and Carlson both opted to reserve 
  the right to recall Wilson for redirect; however, neither defendant recalled 
  her.Â  
Wilson averred Carlson was in bed with her on the morning 
  DeWitt was attacked.Â  She claimed that Carlson had gotten up that morning to 
  get her son to school on time, and, therefore, could not have been at the site 
  of the shooting.Â  The State then called the principal of the school Wilsonâ€™s 
  son attended.Â  The principal testified that Wilsonâ€™s son had been tardy the 
  morning of the attack and had not checked into the office when he arrived.Â  

Carlsonâ€™s argument is not preserved.Â  We reiterate, Carlson 
  cannot use an objection by his co-defendant to preserve an issue for appellate 
  review.Â  State v. Carriker, 269 S.C. 553, 555, 238 S.E.2d 678, 678 (1977).Â  
  Additionally, Carlson did not enter a copy of the statement into the record, 
  so review is not possible.Â  In State v. Mitchell, 330 S.C. 189, 498 S.E.2d 
  642, (1998), the appellant argued the trial judge improperly refused to consider 
  a written statement, allegedly made by one of the Stateâ€™s eyewitnesses, which 
  was discovered after the jury began deliberating.Â  The court noted that â€œthe 
  statement is not in the record on appeal and therefore this Court does not know 
  exactly what information it contained.â€Â  Id. at 199, 498 S.E.2d at 647; 
  see also State v. Hutto, 279 S.C. 131, 303 S.E.2d 90 (1983) (affirming 
  dismissal of indictment for insufficiency of evidence where the State failed 
  to meet its burden of presenting a record which was sufficiently complete to 
  permit review by the appellate entity).Â  The burden is on the appellant to provide 
  a sufficient record for review.Â  State v. Williams, 321 S.C. 455, 464 
  n.4, 469 S.E.2d 49, 55 n.4 (1996); State v. Tyndall, 336 S.C. 8, 17, 
  518 S.E.2d 278, 283 (Ct. App. 1999).
Moreover, Carlson has not established a Brady violation.Â  
  Suppression by the prosecution of evidence favorable to an accused upon request 
  violates due process where the evidence is material either to guilt or to punishment, 
  irrespective of the good faith or bad faith of the prosecution.Â  State v. 
  Taylor, 333 S.C. 159, 508 S.E.2d 870 (1998) (citing Brady v. Maryland, 
  373 U.S. 83 (1963)); Gibson v. State, 334 S.C. 515, 524, 514 S.E.2d 320, 
  324 (1999).Â  Brady only requires disclosure of evidence that is both 
  favorable to the accused and material to guilt or punishment.Â  Taylor, 
  333 S.C. 159, 508 S.E.2d 870 (citing United States v. Bagley, 473 U.S. 
  667 (1985)).
A Brady claim is based on the requirement of due process. 
  Â To establish a due process violation, an accused must demonstrate that the 
  evidence was (1) favorable to the accused; (2) in the possession of or known 
  to the prosecution; (3) suppressed by the prosecution; and (4) material to guilt 
  or punishment.Â  Gibson at 524, 514 S.E.2d at 324 (citing Kyles v. 
  Whitley, 514 U.S. 419, 432-42 (1995); Brady, 373 U.S. at 87; State 
  v. Von Dohlen, 322 S.C. 234, 241, 471 S.E.2d 689, 693 (1996)); State 
  v. Jarrell, 350 S.C. 90, 107, 564 S.E.2d 362, 372 (Ct. App. 2002), cert. 
  denied.Â  The rule applies to impeachment evidence as well as exculpatory 
  evidence.Â  Gibson at 524, 514 S.E.2d at 324 (citing Bagley, 473 
  U.S. at 676).
There are three categories of Brady violations: (1) 
  cases involving nondisclosed evidence or perjured testimony about which the 
  prosecutor knew or should have known; (2) cases in which the defendant specifically 
  requested the nondisclosed evidence; and (3) cases in which the defendant made 
  no request or only a general request for Brady material.Â  Gibson 
  at 524-25, 514 S.E.2d at 325 (citing United States v. Agurs, 427 U.S. 
  97 (1976)).Â  
Prior to trial, defense counsel moved to compel copies of 
  any Brady material and any statements made during the investigation of 
  the case.Â  In â€œspecific-requestâ€ or â€œgeneral- or no-requestâ€ situations such 
  as this one, favorable evidence is considered material for Brady purposes.Â  
  Gibson at 525, 514 S.E.2d at 325.Â  Reversible error occurs when the prosecution 
  suppresses material that had a reasonable probability of achieving a different 
  result in the proceeding if it had been disclosed to the defense, thereby undermining 
  confidence in the outcome of the trial.Â  Id.Â  Exculpatory evidence is 
  that which creates a reasonable doubt about the defendantâ€™s guilt.Â  State 
  v. Forney, 321 S.C. 353, 468 S.E.2d 641 (1996); Jarrell at 107, 564 
  S.E.2d at 372.Â  The court must make the materiality determination on a case-by-case 
  basis.Â  Gibson at 525, 514 S.E.2d at 325.
We cannot say that nondisclosure of the transcript of Wilsonâ€™s 
  prior inconsistent statement to the defense undermined confidence in the outcome 
  of the trial.Â  Courts have held that when defense counsel is given the opportunity 
  to review and use the inconsistent statement in cross-examination, as was done 
  here, there is no reasonable probability the outcome of the trial would have 
  been different.Â  See, e.g., Sheppard v. State, 357 S.C. 646, 660, 
  594 S.E.2d 462, 470 (2004).Â  Here, Carlson was given a copy of the statement, 
  and he was afforded the opportunity to recall Wilson, which he did not do.Â  
  Additionally, Wilsonâ€™s impeachment did not turn on the transcript, but on the 
  school principalâ€™s testimony that Wilsonâ€™s son had been tardy on the morning 
  of the shooting.Â  Thus, the suppression did not undermine confidence in the 
  outcome of the trial.Â  
VII. Request for New Trial
Carlson argues the trial judge erred in allowing the prosecution 
  to continue cross-examining Wilson using the forty-page transcript of her prior 
  statement after defense counsel objected.Â  He contends a new trial is warranted.Â  
  We disagree. 
Counsel for Carlson did not make a contemporaneous objection 
  or provide a copy of the statement in the record for appellate review.Â  Carlson 
  has failed to establish a Brady violation and thus cannot show entitlement 
  to a new trial.Â  Finally, Carlson did not request a new trial on the basis of 
  Brady.Â  Issues not raised and ruled upon by the trial court are not preserved 
  for appellate review.Â  State v. Dunbar, 356 S.C. 138, 587 S.E.2d 691 
  (2003).Â  
VIII. Use of Prior Criminal Record
Carlsonâ€™s final argument on appeal is that the trial court 
  erred in informing him that any criminal conviction would be admissible against 
  him if he took the witness stand.Â  This argument fails for several reasons. 

Carlson did not testify.Â  The issue, therefore, is not preserved 
  for our review.Â  In State v. Glenn, 285 S.C. 384, 330 S.E.2d 285 (1985), 
  the South Carolina Supreme Court observed:

In Luce v. United States, 469 U.S. 38, 105 S.Ct. 460, 
  83 L.E.2d 443 (1994), the United States Supreme Court recently refused to review 
  a claim, under Federal Rule of Evidence 609(a), of improper impeachment with 
  a prior conviction.Â  The Court reasoned that when the defendant does not testify, 
  appellate review is too speculative for several reasons.Â  Those reasons include: 
  the freedom of the trial judge to later alter his ruling; the possibility the 
  prosecution may not have sought to impeach the defendant with the prior convictions; 
  the likelihood that an adverse ruling might not have been the real motivation 
  for the defendantâ€™s decision not to testify; and the inability of the appellate 
  court to review any error for harmlessness.

Glenn at 385, 330 S.E.2d at 285-86.Â  The Glenn 
  court adopted Luce, holding: â€œwhen the trial judge chooses to make a 
  preliminary ruling on the admissibility of prior convictions to impeach a defendant 
  and the defendant does not testify at trial, the claim of improper impeachment 
  is not preserved for review.â€Â  Id. at 385, 330 S.E.2d at 286; see 
  also State v. Ford, 334 S.C. 444, 454, 513 S.E.2d 385, 390 (Ct. App. 
  1999).Â  
Further, the trial judge never ruled on the admissibility 
  of Carlsonâ€™s prior convictions.Â  Carlson made a motion in limine to exclude 
  any mention of Carlsonâ€™s prior criminal record, which the trial judge took under 
  advisement.Â  After the State rested its case, the trial judge informed both 
  defendants of their right to testify and stated: â€œif you do testify, if you 
  have some prior record, then that will come into evidence on the basis of your 
  believability and credibility, not on the basis of your guilt or innocence with 
  regard to these charges . . . .â€Â  Immediately after the address, the trial judge 
  asked them whether they had any questions about their right to remain silent 
  or their right to testify. 
Carlson contends that the judgeâ€™s statement constituted 
  a ruling on the prior motion in limine.Â  However, we find the trial judge 
  was only generally advising the defendants of the possibility they would be 
  impeached.Â  Immediately prior to the colloquy, Carlsonâ€™s counsel requested that 
  the judge â€œallow him to defer his decision [whether to testify] until after 
  we present the rest of our case.â€Â  The judge consented.Â  After Carlsonâ€™s witness 
  testified, counsel for Carlson asked the court for a moment to discuss with 
  Carlson whether to call another witness or testify.Â  He chose to rest.Â  Carlson 
  never sought clarification on the ruling as to which charges would be admissible.Â  
  We are not persuaded a final ruling was made.
Carlson did not testify.Â  Therefore, pursuant to 
  Glenn, the issue is not preserved for our review.
CONCLUSION
We hold that Carlson consented to the procedure used for determining 
  the admissibility of the photo lineup.Â  The in-court identification was proper 
  because the suggestive photograph was not used, no specific contemporaneous 
  objection was raised, and there were sufficient indicia of reliability to indicate 
  the in-court identification had an independent basis.Â  We find no abuse of discretion 
  in the judgeâ€™s decision not to order the jury to review the entire testimony 
  of DeWitt.Â  Additionally, the bailiffâ€™s action in relaying the message from 
  the jury to the judge was not improper.Â  Carlsonâ€™s Brady claim is not 
  preserved.Â  Carlson failed to demonstrate a Brady violation.Â  Finally, 
  we hold the trial judgeâ€™s address to the defendants was not a ruling on the 
  admissibility of Carlsonâ€™s prior criminal record, and, even if it were, the 
  issue is not preserved.Â  Accordingly, Carlsonâ€™s convictions are hereby 
 AFFIRMED. 
 BEATTY and SHORT, JJ., concur.

 
   [1]  We note that Carlsonâ€™s appellate counsel was not his trial 
    counsel.
