description: In this Workersâ€™ Compensation case, the Appellant contends the Circuit Court erred in holding that the Appellant insurance carrier was not entitled to reimbursement from the Second Injury Fund for compensation payments made by the Appellant insurance carrier for the total loss of the claimantâ€™s right leg.
text:
FACTS


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Liberty Mutual Insurance Company, Appellant,
v.
South Carolina Second Injury Fund, Respondent.
In Re:
Timothy Paul Williams, Employee,
v.
Tate Metalworks/Liberty Mutual Insurance Company,
Employer/Carrier.
      
    
  


Appeal From Spartanburg County
Â J. Derham Cole, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 3949
Heard February 9, 2005 â€“ Filed February 
  22, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Pope D. Johnson, III, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Robert M. Cook, II, of Batesberg-Leeseville, and Terry Michael Mauldin, of 
  Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  


ANDERSON, J.:Â  Timothy Paul Williams (Claimant) lost his right leg in a work-related 
  accident.Â  Liberty Mutual Insurance Company (Liberty) sought reimbursement for 
  compensation benefit payments from the South Carolina Second Injury Fund (the 
  Fund) based on Claimantâ€™s preexisting impairment.Â  The circuit court ruled that 
  Liberty was not entitled to reimbursement of the controverted payments.Â  We 
  affirm.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
Claimant sustained 
  a compensable injury when a steel I-beam fell on his legs.Â  His right leg was 
  essentially amputated above the knee in the accident, and his left leg was crushed.Â  
  Claimant was awarded 100% permanent partial disability to his right leg and 
  45% permanent partial disability to his left leg.Â  The orders of the single 
  commissioner, the appellate panel, and the circuit court all found that Claimantâ€™s 
  100% disability to the right leg was caused by the industrial accident alone, 
  and his diabetes, a preexisting impairment, played no role in the loss of that 
  leg.Â  
Liberty seeks reimbursement 
  from the Fund pursuant to section 42-9-400 of the South Carolina Code (1985), 
  because of Claimantâ€™s preexisting diabetes.Â  The Fund reimbursed Libertyâ€™s claim 
  regarding all medical payments and disability compensation, with the exception 
  of the 100% permanent disability paid for the right leg.Â  The Fund argues the 
  claim does not qualify for reimbursement because the total loss of the right 
  leg was solely attributable to the industrial accident.Â  The hearing commissioner 
  ruled in the Fundâ€™s favor.Â  The appellate panel reversed.Â  However, the appellate 
  panelâ€™s decision was reversed by the circuit court.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The South Carolina Administrative Procedures Act (APA) establishes the standard 
  for judicial review of decisions of the workers' compensation commission.Â  Hargrove 
  v. Titan Textile Co., 360 S.C. 276, 599 S.E.2d 604 (Ct. App. 2004); see 
  Lark v. Bi-Lo, Inc., 276 S.C. 130, 276 S.E.2d 304 (1981); 
  Gibson v. Spartanburg Sch. Dist. No. 3, 338 S.C. 510, 526 S.E.2d 
  725 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  A reviewing court may reverse or modify a decision of 
  an agency if the findings, inferences, conclusions, or decisions of that agency 
  are â€œclearly erroneous in view of the reliable, probative and substantial evidence 
  on the whole record.â€Â  Bursey v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Health and Envtl. 
  Control, 360 S.C. 135, 141, 600 S.E.2d 80, 84 (Ct. App. 2004); S.C. 
  Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-380(A)(6)(e) (Supp. 2003).Â  Under the scope of review established 
  in the APA, this Court may not substitute its judgment for that of the commission 
  as to the weight of the evidence on questions of fact, but may reverse where 
  the decision is affected by an error of law.Â  Stone v. Traylor Bros., Inc., 
  360 S.C. 271, 600 S.E.2d 551 (Ct. App. 2004); Frame v. Resort Servs., Inc., 
  357 S.C. 520, 593 S.E.2d 491 (Ct. App. 2004); Stephen v. Avins Constr. Co., 
  324 S.C. 334, 478 S.E.2d 74 (Ct. App. 1996); S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-380(A)(6)(d) 
  (Supp. 2003).Â  
The substantial evidence rule of the APA governs the standard of review in 
  a workersâ€™ compensation decision. Frame, 357 S.C. 520, 593 S.E.2d 491; 
  Corbin v. Kohler Co., 351 S.C. 613, 571 S.E.2d 92 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  
  This Courtâ€™s review is limited to deciding whether the commissionâ€™s decision 
  is unsupported by substantial evidence or is controlled by some error of law.Â  
  See Grant v. Grant Textiles, 361 S.C. 188, 603 S.E.2d 858 
  (Ct. App. 2004); Gibson, 338 S.C. at 517, 526 S.E.2d at 728-29; 
  see also Dukes v. Rural Metro Corp, 356 S.C. 107, 109, 587 S.E.2d 
  687, 688 (2003) (â€œThis Court will not overturn a decision by the Workersâ€™ Compensation 
  Commission unless the determination is unsupported by substantial evidence.â€); 
  Lyles v. Quantum Chem. Co. (Emery), 315 S.C. 440, 434 S.E.2d 
  292 (Ct. App. 1993) (noting that in reviewing decision of workersâ€™ compensation 
  commission, court of appeals will not set aside its findings unless they are 
  not supported by substantial evidence or they are controlled by error of law).
Substantial evidence is not a mere scintilla of evidence, nor the evidence 
  viewed blindly from one side of the case, but is evidence which, considering 
  the record as a whole, would allow reasonable minds to reach the conclusion 
  the administrative agency reached in order to justify its action.Â  Pratt 
  v. Morris Roofing, Inc., 357 S.C. 619, 594 S.E.2d 272 (2004); Jones v. 
  Georgia-Pacific Corp., 355 S.C. 413, 586 S.E.2d 111 (2003); Etheredge 
  v. Monsanto Co., 349 S.C. 451, 562 S.E.2d 679 (Ct. App. 2002); Broughton 
  v. South of the Border, 336 S.C. 488, 520 S.E.2d 634 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  
  The appellate panel is the ultimate fact finder in workersâ€™ compensation cases 
  and is not bound by the single commissionerâ€™s findings of fact.Â  Gibson, 
  338 S.C. at 517, 526 S.E.2d at 729; Muir v. C.R. Bard, Inc., 336 
  S.C. 266, 519 S.E.2d 583 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  â€œThe final determination of witness 
  credibility and the weight to be accorded evidence is reserved to the Appellate 
  Panel.â€Â  Frame, 357 S.C. at 528, 593 S.E.2d at 495 (citing Shealy 
  v. Aiken County, 341 S.C. 448, 535 S.E.2d 438 (2000)); Parsons 
  v. Georgetown Steel, 318 S.C. 63, 456 S.E.2d 366 (1995); Gibson, 
  338 S.C. at 517, 526 S.E.2d at 729).Â  The possibility of drawing two inconsistent 
  conclusions from the evidence does not prevent an administrative agencyâ€™s findings 
  from being supported by substantial evidence.Â  Dukes, 356 S.C. 107, 587 
  S.E.2d 687; Sharpe v. Case Produce, Inc., 336 S.C. 154, 519 S.E.2d 
  102 (1999); Durant v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Health & Envtl. Control, 
  361 S.C. 416, 604 S.E.2d 704 (Ct. App. 2004); Corbin v. Kohler Co., 351 
  S.C. 613, 571 S.E.2d 92 (Ct. App. 2002); Muir, 336 S.C. at 282, 
  519 S.E.2d at 591.Â  Where there are conflicts in the evidence over a factual 
  issue, the findings of the appellate panel are conclusive.Â  Hargrove 
  at 290, 599 S.E.2d at 611; Etheredge, 349 S.C. at 455, 562 S.E.2d 
  at 681.
The findings of an administrative agency are presumed correct and will be set 
  aside only if unsupported by substantial evidence.Â  Anderson v. Baptist Med. 
  Ctr., 343 S.C. 487, 541 S.E.2d 526 (2001); Hicks v. Piedmont Cold 
  Storage, Inc., 335 S.C. 46, 515 S.E.2d 532 (1999); Frame at 
  528, 593 S.E.2d at 495.Â  It is not within our province to reverse findings of 
  the appellate panel which are supported by substantial evidence.Â  Pratt, 
  357 S.C. at 274-75, 594 S.E.2d at 622; Broughton, 336 S.C. at 
  496, 520 S.E.2d at 637.Â  The appellate court is prohibited from overturning 
  findings of fact of the appellate panel, unless there is no reasonable probability 
  the facts could be as related by the witness upon whose testimony the finding 
  was based.Â  Hargrove at 290, 599 S.E.2d at 611; Etheredge, 
  349 S.C. at 455-56, 562 S.E.2d at 681.
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Principles of Statutory Construction
The cardinal rule of statutory interpretation is to ascertain the intent of 
  the legislature.Â  State v. Scott, 351 S.C. 584, 588, 571 S.E.2d 
  700, 702 (2002); Georgia-Carolina Bail Bonds, Inc. v. County of Aiken, 
  354 S.C. 18, 579 S.E.2d 334 (Ct. App. 2003); see also Gordon v. Phillips 
  Utils. Inc., Op. No. 25930 (S.C. filed January 24, 2005) (Shearouse Adv. 
  Sh. No. 4 at 44) (â€œThe primary purpose in construing a statute is to ascertain 
  legislative intent.â€); Olson v. Faculty House of Carolina, Inc., 
  344 S.C. 194, 205, 544 S.E.2d 38, 44 (Ct. App. 2001) (â€œThe quintessence of statutory 
  construction is legislative intent.â€).Â  A statute should be given a reasonable 
  and practical construction consistent with the purpose and policy expressed 
  in the statute.Â  Davis v. NationsCredit Fin. Servs. Corp., 326 S.C. 83, 
  484 S.E.2d 471 (1997); Daisy Outdoor Adver. Co. v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of 
  Transp., 352 S.C. 113, 120, 572 S.E.2d 462, 466 (Ct. App. 2002); 
  Stephen v. Avins Constr. Co., 324 S.C. 334, 478 S.E.2d 74 (Ct. 
  App. 1996).Â  All rules of statutory construction are subservient to the one 
  that legislative intent must prevail if it can be reasonably discovered in the 
  language used, and that language must be construed in the light of the intended 
  purpose of the statute.Â  McClanahan v. Richland County Council, 350 S.C. 
  433, 567 S.E.2d 240 (2002); Ray Bell Constr. Co. v. Sch. Dist. of Greenville 
  County, 331 S.C. 19, 501 S.E.2d 725 (1998); State v. Morgan, 
  352 S.C. 359, 574 S.E.2d 203 (Ct. App. 2002); State v. Hudson, 
  336 S.C. 237, 519 S.E.2d 577 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  The determination of legislative 
  intent is a matter of law.Â  Charleston County Parks & Recreation Commâ€™n 
  v. Somers, 319 S.C. 65, 459 S.E.2d 841 (1995); South Carolina 
  Uninsured Employerâ€™s Fund v. House, 360 S.C. 468, 602 S.E.2d 81 (Ct. App. 
  2004); Olson, 344 S.C. at 207, 544 S.E.2d at 45.
The legislatureâ€™s intent should be ascertained primarily from the plain language 
  of the statute.Â  State v. Landis, 362 S.C. 97, 606 S.E.2d 503 (Ct. App. 
  2004); Morgan, 352 S.C. at 366, 574 S.E.2d at 206; Stephen, 
  324 S.C. at 339, 478 S.E.2d at 77.Â  The language must also be read in a sense 
  which harmonizes with its subject matter and accords with its general purpose.Â  
  Mun. Assâ€™n of South Carolina v. AT & T Communications of S. States, Inc., 
  361 S.C. 576, 606 S.E.2d 468 (2004); Hitachi Data Sys. v. Leatherman, 
  309 S.C. 174, 420 S.E.2d 843 (1992); Morgan, 352 S.C. at 366, 
  574 S.E.2d at 206; Hudson, 336 S.C. at 246, 519 S.E.2d at 582.Â  
  The courtâ€™s primary function in interpreting a statute is to ascertain the intent 
  of the General Assembly.Â  Smith, 350 S.C. at 87, 564 S.E.2d at 
  361.Â  A statute must receive a practical and reasonable interpretation consistent 
  with the â€œdesignâ€ of the legislature.Â  Id. â€œOnce the legislature has 
  made [a] choice, there is no room for the courts to impose a different judgment 
  based upon their own notions of public policy.â€Â  South Carolina Farm Bureau 
  Mut. Ins. Co. v. Mumford, 299 S.C. 14, 19, 382 S.E.2d 11, 14 (Ct. 
  App. 1989).
When faced with an undefined statutory term, the court must interpret the term 
  in accord with its usual and customary meaning.Â  Branch v. City of Myrtle 
  Beach, 340 S.C. 405, 532 S.E.2d 289 (2000); Strother v. Lexington County 
  Recreation Commâ€™n, 332 S.C. 54, 504 S.E.2d 117 (1998); Hudson, 
  336 S.C. at 246, 519 S.E.2d at 581; see also Santee Cooper 
  Resort v. South Carolina Pub. Serv. Commâ€™n, 298 S.C. 179, 184, 379 
  S.E.2d 119, 122 (1989) (â€œWords used in a statute should be taken in their ordinary 
  and popular significance unless there is something in the statute requiring 
  a different interpretation.â€).Â  â€œThe terms must be construed in context and 
  their meaning determined by looking at the other terms used in the statute.â€Â  
  Hinton v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Prob., Parole and Pardon Servs., 357 S.C. 327, 
  332-33, 592 S.E.2d 335, 338 (Ct. App. 2004), cert. granted (Jan. 7, 2005) 
  (citingÂ  S. Mut. Church Ins. Co. v. South Carolina Windstorm & Hail Underwriting 
  Assâ€™n, 306 S.C. 339, 342, 412 S.E.2d 377, 379 (1991)); Dupree, 354 
  S.C. at 693, 583 S.E.2d at 446).Â  
Courts should consider not merely the language of the particular clause being 
  construed, but the word and its meaning in conjunction with the purpose of the 
  whole statute and the policy of the law.Â  Whitner v. State, 328 S.C. 
  1, 16, 492 S.E.2d 777, 779 (1997); see also State v. Gordon, 356 
  S.C. 143, 152, 588 S.E.2d 105, 110 (2003) (â€œ[T]he court should not consider 
  the particular clause being construed in isolation, but should read it in conjunction 
  with the purpose of the whole statute and the policy of the law.â€); Stephen 
  at 340, 478 S.E.2d at 77 (finding statutory provisions should be given reasonable 
  and practical construction consistent with purpose and policy of entire act).Â  
  Statutes must be read as a whole and sections which are part of the same general 
  statutory scheme must be construed together and given effect, if it can be done 
  by any reasonable construction.Â  Tillotson v. Keith Smith Builders, 357 
  S.C. 554, 593 S.E.2d 621 (Ct. App. 2004); Higgins v. State, 307 
  S.C. 446, 415 S.E.2d 799 (1992).Â  Dictionaries can be helpful tools during the 
  initial stages of legal research for the purpose of defining statutory terms.Â  
  Heilker v. Zoning Bd. of Appeals for City of Beaufort, 346 S.C. 
  401, 552 S.E.2d 42 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  
If a statuteâ€™s language is unambiguous and clear, there is no need to employ 
  the rules of statutory construction and this Court has no right to look for 
  or impose another meaning.Â  Tilley v. Pacesetter Corp., 355 S.C. 361, 
  585 S.E.2d 292 (2003); Paschal v. State Election Commâ€™n, 317 S.C. 
  434, 454 S.E.2d 890 (1995); Cowan v. Allstate Ins. Co., 351 S.C. 
  626, 631, 571 S.E.2d 715, 717 (Ct. App. 2002); see also City 
  of Camden v. Brassell, 326 S.C. 556, 561, 486 S.E.2d 492, 495 (Ct. 
  App. 1997) (â€œWhere the language of the statute is clear and explicit, the court 
  cannot rewrite the statute and inject matters into it which are not in the legislatureâ€™s 
  language.â€).Â  When the terms of a statute are clear, the court must apply those 
  terms according to their literal meaning.Â  Patterson v. State, 359 S.C. 
  115, 592 S.E.2d 150 (2004); Holley v. Mount Vernon Mills, Inc., 
  312 S.C. 320, 440 S.E.2d 373 (1994); Carolina Alliance for Fair Employment 
  v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Labor, Licensing, & Regulation, 337 S.C. 476, 
  523 S.E.2d 795 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  What a legislature says in the text of a statute 
  is considered the best evidence of the legislative intent or will.Â  Wigfall 
  v. Tideland Utils, Inc., 354 S.C. 100, 580 S.E.2d 100 (2003); Bayle v. 
  South Carolina Depâ€™t of Transp., 344 S.C. 115, 542 S.E.2d 736 (Ct. 
  App. 2001).Â  The words of a statute must be given their plain and ordinary meaning 
  without resorting to subtle or forced construction.Â  AT & T Communications, 
  361 S.C. 576, 606 S.E.2d 468; Durham v. United Cos. Fin. Corp., 
  331 S.C. 600, 503 S.E.2d 465 (1998); Worsley Cos. v. South Carolina Depâ€™t 
  of Health & Envtl. Control, 351 S.C. 97, 102, 567 S.E.2d 907, 
  910 (Ct. App. 2002); see also Timmons v. South Carolina Tricentennial 
  Commâ€™n, 254 S.C. 378, 175 S.E.2d 805 (1970) (providing that where 
  the language of the statute is clear and explicit, the court cannot rewrite 
  the statute and inject matters into it that are not in the legislatureâ€™s language.).Â  
  Under the plain meaning rule, it is not the courtâ€™s place to change the meaning 
  of a clear and unambiguous statute. Â Vaughn v. Bernhardt, 345 S.C. 196, 
  547 S.E.2d 869 (2001); Hodges v. Rainey, 341 S.C. 79, 533 S.E.2d 
  578 (2000); Bayle, 344 S.C. at 122, 542 S.E.2d at 739.
If the language of an act gives rise to doubt or uncertainty as to legislative 
  intent, the construing court may search for that intent beyond the borders of 
  the act itself.Â  Morgan, 352 S.C. at 367, 574 S.E.2d at 207; see 
  also Wade v. Berkeley County, 348 S.C. 224, 229, 559 
  S.E.2d 586, 588 (2002) (â€œ[W]here a statute is ambiguous, the Court must construe 
  the terms of the statute.â€). An ambiguity in a statute should be resolved in 
  favor of a just, beneficial, and equitable operation of the law.Â  Hudson, 
  336 S.C. at 247, 519 S.E.2d at 582; Brassell, 326 S.C. at 561, 
  486 S.E.2d at 495; City of Sumter Police Depâ€™t v. One (1) 1992 Blue Mazda 
  Truck, 330 S.C. 371, 498 S.E.2d 894 (Ct. App. 1998).Â  In construing 
  a statute, the court looks to the language as a whole in light of its manifest 
  purpose.Â  State v. Dawkins, 352 S.C. 162, 573 S.E.2d 783 (2002); 
  Adams v. Texfi Indus., 320 S.C. 213, 464 S.E.2d 109 (1995); Burgess 
  v. Nationwide Mut. Ins. Co., 361 S.C. 196, 603 S.E.2d 861 (Ct. App. 2004).
II.Â  Interpretation of Section 42-9-400
The instant case requires this Court to determine the scope and reach of section 
  42-9-400 of the South Carolina Code (1985).Â  Specifically, the issue is whether 
  the statute permits Liberty to recover compensation payments from the Fund when 
  the injury for which reimbursement is sought was not affected by the preexisting 
  impairment. 
Section 42-7-310 of the South Carolina Code (1985) establishes the Second Injury 
  Fund.Â  The purpose of the Fund is to â€œencourage the employment of disabled or 
  handicapped persons without penalizing an employer with greater liability if 
  the employee is injured because of his preexisting condition.â€Â  South Carolina 
  Second Injury Fund v. Liberty Mut. Ins. Co., 353 S.C. 117, 122, 576 S.E.2d 
  199, 202 (Ct. App. 2003) (quoting Liberty Mut. Ins. Co. v. South Carolina 
  Second Injury Fund, 318 S.C. 516, 518, 458 S.E.2d 550, 551 (1995)).Â  The 
  Fund accomplishes this goal by absorbing some of the risk that such a worker 
  will become injured in the workplace.Â  Its creation allows the employer, or 
  his insurance carrier, to seek compensation from the Fund when an employee with 
  a prior permanent physical impairment incurs a subsequent disability in the 
  workplace.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-9-400 (a) (1985).
Section 42-9-400 (a) provides:Â  

If an employee who has a permanent physical impairment 
  from any cause or origin incurs a subsequent disability from injury by accident 
  arising out of and in the course of his employment, resulting in compensation 
  and medical payments liability or either, for disability that is substantially 
  greater, by reason of the combined effects of the preexisting impairment and 
  subsequent injury or by reason of the aggravation of the preexisting impairment, 
  than that which would have resulted from the subsequent injury alone, the employer 
  or his insurance carrier shall in the first instance pay all awards of compensation 
  and medical benefits provided by this Title; but such employer or his insurance 
  carrier shall be reimbursed from the Second Injury Fund as created by Â§ 42-7-310 
  for compensation and medical benefits in the following manner: 
(1) 
  Reimbursement of all compensation benefit payments payable subsequent to those 
  payable for the first seventy-eight weeks following the injury.
(2) Reimbursement of fifty percent of medical payments 
  in excess of three thousand dollars during the first seventy-eight weeks following 
  the injury and then reimbursement of all medical benefit payments payable subsequent 
  to the first seventy-eight weeks following the injury; provided, however, 
  in order to obtain reimbursement for medical expense during the first seventy-eight 
  weeks following the subsequent injury, an employer or carrier must establish 
  that his liability for medical payments is substantially greater, by reason 
  of the combined effects of the preexisting impairment and subsequent injury 
  or by reason of the aggravation of the preexisting impairment, than that which 
  would have resulted from the subsequent injury alone.

S.C. Code Ann. (1985).
Liberty argues the appellate panel correctly determined 
  this section clearly and unambiguously sets forth the requirements, which, when 
  met, trigger the right of reimbursement.Â  Specifically, Liberty claims that 
  a plain reading of section 9-42-400(a)(1) gives it the right to reimbursement 
  for all compensation benefit payments without regard to whether a nexus 
  exists between the payments and the preexisting impairment.Â  However, an examination 
  of the law and its application to these facts reveals that the circuit court 
  properly rejected this reading of the statute.
This is an issue of first impression in South Carolina.Â  
  After carefully considering the facts of this case; the nature of the injury; 
  the existing case law, which allows reimbursement to be limited to either compensation 
  or medical liability when factually supported; and the purpose of the Fund, 
  this Court concludes as a matter of law Liberty can only be reimbursed for the 
  liability proximately owed to the prior disability.
Claimant, who suffered from diabetes, was working when 
  the steel I-beam fell and crushed his legs.Â  At the time the I-beam fell onto 
  his right leg, it essentially traumatically amputated the right leg above the 
  knee.Â  In addition, the I-beam crushed and fractured his left leg.Â  The preexisting 
  diabetes acted to exacerbate the condition of his left leg and contributed to 
  increased medical expenses, but the diabetes had no impact on the amputation 
  of his right leg or the disability rating given to Claimant because of the loss 
  of his right leg.Â  Therefore, the preexisting diabetes had no impact on the 
  portion of the award paid for the injury to the right leg.
In Liberty Mutual Insurance Company v. South Carolina 
  Second Injury Fund, 318 S.C. 516, 518, 458 S.E.2d 550, 551-52 (1995), the 
  supreme court ruled a carrier was entitled to reimbursement for medical costs 
  but not disability payments.Â  The court noted that while diabetes exacerbated 
  the workplace injury and ultimately required a double amputation, the workplace 
  accident alone was enough to cause the claimant to become permanently and totally 
  disabled.Â  Id. at 517, 458 S.E.2d at 551.Â  Importantly, the court recognized 
  the accident was sufficient to trigger permanent and total disability payments.Â  
  The court approved the circuit courtâ€™s interpretation of section 42-9-400(a) 
  that â€œif a carrier incurs greater liability for compensation and/or medical 
  payments, he is entitled to reimbursement of those.â€Â  Id. at 519, 458 
  S.E.2d at 551.Â  Liberty had incurred greater medical payments because of the 
  claimantâ€™s diabetes; however, Liberty â€œdid not incur greater compensation payments 
  as the accident rendered [the claimant] totally disabled and [the claimant]â€™s 
  diabetes did not increase these payments.â€Â  Id. at 519, 458 S.E.2d at 
  551-52.Â  Thus, the insurer could not recover reimbursement for the compensation 
  payments, but the court allowed reimbursement for the medical expenses which 
  were attributable to the diabetes.
Liberty Mutual stands for the proposition that 
  medical and compensation reimbursement do not necessarily follow from each other, 
  but are, instead, fact dependant.Â  Following the logic of Liberty Mutual, 
  it is appropriate to consider the injuries to the right and left legs separately.Â  
  The diabetes did not exacerbate the injury to the right leg and did not add 
  to the medical expenses.Â  The statutory scheme of scheduling the loss of each 
  individual member buttresses our conclusion.Â  See, e.g., S.C. Code Ann. 
  Â§ 42-9-30 (15) (1985) (providing the amount of compensation and the period of 
  disability for the loss of a leg).
We are compelled toward this result by the rules of 
  statutory interpretation discussed in Liberty Mutual.Â  There, the court 
  stated the â€œprimary function in interpreting a statute is to ascertain the intent 
  of the legislatureâ€ and â€œ[t]he real purpose of the legislature will prevail 
  over the literal import of the words.â€Â  Liberty Mutual, 318 S.C. at 519, 
  458 S.E.2d at 551 (citations omitted).Â  The court explained the intent and purpose 
  of the Fund â€œis to encourage the employment of disabled or handicapped persons 
  without penalizing an employer with greater liability if the employee is injured 
  because of his preexisiting condition.â€Â  Id.Â  The interpretation of section 
  42-9-400 proffered by Liberty in the case sub judice does not advance 
  the purpose of the Fund as explicated by the Liberty Mutual court.Â  Instead, 
  Libertyâ€™s reading of the statute would provide the insurer with a windfall unrelated 
  to Claimantâ€™s preexisting condition.
CONCLUSION
For the reasons discussed above, the circuit courtâ€™s 
  interpretation of section 42-9-400, providing for reimbursement for the left 
  leg, but not the right, is 
AFFIRMED.
BEATTY and SHORT, JJ., concur.

title: State v. Passmore
description: The issue on appeal is whether a family court judge has the constitutional authority to give a contempt sentence in excess of six months without granting a jury trial.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
The State, Respondent,
v.
Melissa Passmore, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
Â Amy C. Sutherland, Family Court 
  Judge
Â Stephen S. Bartlett, Family Court 
  Judge

Opinion No. 3950
Submitted February 1, 2005 â€“ Filed 
  February 22, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Assistant Appellate 
  Defender Tara S. Taggart, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John 
  W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, and Senior 
  Assistant Attorney General Norman Mark Rapoport, all of Columbia; and Solicitor 
  Robert M. Ariail, of Greenville, for Respondent.
      
    
  

ANDERSON, J.:Â  A family court judge found Melissa Passmore (Appellant) 
  in willful contempt of a prior order and sentenced her to one year in prison.Â  
  Appellant contends her sentence violates the United States Constitution.Â  We 
  agree but affirm. [1] 
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
In 1996 the family court issued a written order 
  requiring Appellant and her husband to ensure that their eight-year-old daughter 
  â€œregularly attend school and see to it that the minor(s) does/do so attend school 
  for the remainder of this school year and future school years, under penalty 
  of law.â€Â  In February of 2002, when their daughter was fourteen years old, Appellant 
  and her husband were summoned to a rule to show cause hearing to answer allegations 
  of educational neglect in connection with their daughter.Â  The family court 
  continued the hearing so that the Passmores could obtain counsel.Â  The proceeding 
  resumed in April of 2002, and the family court judge found Appellant and her 
  husband in willful contempt of the 1996 order.Â  The judge sentenced both of 
  them to one year in prison, and she took emergency protective custody of the 
  Passmoresâ€™ minor daughter.Â  Appellant contends the sentence violated her federal 
  constitutional right to a trial by jury in serious criminal cases.
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  The Constitutional Limitation on the Contempt Power 
â€œThe power to punish for contempt is inherent in all courts.Â  Its existence 
  is essential to the preservation of order in judicial proceedings, and to the 
  enforcement of the judgments, orders and writs of the courts, and consequently 
  to the due administration of justice.â€Â  Curlee v. Howle, 277 S.C. 377, 
  382, 287 S.E.2d 915, 917 (1982) (citing McLeod v. Hite, 272 S.C. 303, 
  251 S.E.2d 746 (1979); State v. Goff, 228 S.C. 17, 88 S.E.2d 788 (1955)).Â  
  The determination of contempt ordinarily resides in the sound discretion of 
  the trial judge.Â  State v. Bevilacqua, 316 S.C. 122, 129, 447 S.E.2d 
  213, 217 (Ct. App. 1994).
Contempt results from the willful disobedience of an order of the court, and 
  before a court may hold a person in contempt, the record must clearly and specifically 
  demonstrate the acts or conduct upon which such finding is based.Â  Curlee 
  at 382, 287 S.E.2d at 918; accord Cheap-Oâ€™s Truck Stop, Inc. v. Cloyd, 
  350 S.C. 596, 606, 567 S.E.2d 514, 519 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  A willful act is â€œone 
  done voluntarily and intentionally with the specific intent to do something 
  the law forbids, or with the specific intent to fail to do something the law 
  requires to be done; that is to say with bad purpose either to disobey or disregard 
  the law.â€ Bevilacqua, 316 S.C. at 129, 447 S.E.2d at 217 (internal quotation 
  marks and citation omitted).Â  Intent for purposes of criminal contempt is subjective, 
  not objective, and must necessarily be ascertained from all the acts, words, 
  and circumstances surrounding the occurrence.Â  Id. (citing State v. 
  Bowers, 270 S.C. 124, 241 S.E.2d 409 (1978)).
Although the contempt power is inherent and essential 
  to the preservation of orderly proceedings, it is not unbounded; the power of 
  contempt is checked by the sacrosanct right to be tried by a jury of oneâ€™s peers.Â  
  Article III, Section 2, of the United States Constitution provides: â€œThe trial 
  of all Crimes, except in Cases of Impeachment, shall be by Jury . . . .â€Â  The 
  right to a jury trial is amplified by the Sixth Amendment, which reads, in part: 
  â€œIn all criminal prosecutions, the accused shall enjoy the right to a speedy 
  and public trial, by an impartial jury of the State and district wherein the 
  crime shall have been committed . . . .â€
Currently, these provisions require a contemnor to be allowed a jury trial 
  when facing a serious sentenceâ€”i.e., one of greater than six months in prison.Â  
  Bloom v. Illinois, 391 U.S. 194 (1968).Â  However, contemnors have not 
  always been afforded the right to a jury trial, even in serious cases.Â  As late 
  as 1964, the United States Supreme Court held that there was no right to a jury 
  trial in a criminal contempt case.Â  See U.S. v. Barnett, 376 U.S. 
  681 (1964).Â  Cheff v. Schnackenberg, 384 U.S. 373 (1966) tempered the 
  longstanding rule expressed in Barnett.Â  In Cheff, the Court upheld 
  a criminal contempt sentence of six months imposed without the benefit of a 
  jury trial.Â  Yet, the Court distinguished the conviction as involving a petty 
  offense and concluded: â€œsentences exceeding six months for criminal contempt 
  may not be imposed by federal courts absent a jury trial or waiver thereof.â€Â  
  Id. at 380.Â  
With Duncan v. Louisiana, 391 U.S. 145 (1968), the Court declared 
  the provisions of the Sixth Amendment were applicable to state governments via 
  the Fourteenth Amendment:

Because we believe that trial by jury in criminal cases is fundamental to the 
  American scheme of justice, we hold that the Fourteenth Amendment guarantees 
  a right of jury trial in all criminal cases whichâ€”were they to be tried in federal 
  courtâ€”would come within the Sixth Amendmentâ€™s guarantee.Â  

Id. at 149 (footnote omitted).Â  The Court further established that â€œin 
  the American States, as in the federal judicial system, a general grant of jury 
  trial for serious offenses is a fundamental right, essential for preventing 
  miscarriages of justice and for assuring that fair trials are provided for all 
  defendants.â€Â  Id. at 157-58.Â  However, the Court was careful to note: 
  â€œwe hold no constitutional doubts about the practices, common in both federal 
  and state courts, of accepting waivers of jury trial and prosecuting petty crimes 
  without extending a right to jury trial.â€Â  Id. at 158 (footnotes omitted).Â  

A pivotal companion case, Bloom v. Illinois, 391 U.S. 194 (1968), presented 
  the question whether a state court could sentence a criminal contemnor to two 
  years imprisonment without a jury trial.Â  The Bloom court began by observing 
  that the Court had â€œconsistently upheld the constitutional power of the state 
  and federal courts to punish any criminal contempt without a jury trial.â€Â  
  Id. at 195-96 (emphasis added).Â  The Court acknowledged the holding of 
  Cheff that contempt was not an intrinsically serious offense and that 
  punishment of six months in prison did not render an offense serious.Â  Justice 
  White, writing for the Bloom majority, then explained:

Our deliberations have convinced us, however, that serious contempts are so 
  nearly like other serious crimes that they are subject to the jury trial provisions 
  of the Constitution, now binding on the States, and that the traditional rule 
  is constitutionally infirm insofar as it permits other than petty contempts 
  to be tried without honoring a demand for a jury trial.Â  
. . . .
Given that criminal contempt is a crime in every fundamental respect, the question 
  is whether it is a crime to which the jury trial provisions of the Constitution

  held that a challenge to sentencing must be raised at trial, or the issue will 
  not be preserved for appellate review.â€Â  Id. at 462, 510 S.E.2d at 425.Â  
  The court rejected Johnstonâ€™s argument that the trial court lacked subject matter 
  jurisdiction, stating: â€œSouth Carolina courts have continued to recognize a 
  distinction between a trial courtâ€™s sentencing authority and its subject matter 
  jurisdiction.â€Â  Id. at 463, 510 S.E.2d 423.Â  However, the court acknowledged 
  that 

if this Court unyieldingly enforces PCR as the only avenue of relief in this 
  case, there is the real threat that Defendant will remain incarcerated beyond 
  the legal sentence due to the additional time it will take to pursue such a 
  remedy.Â  Under these exceptional circumstances, we hold this case should be 
  remanded for resentencing.Â  

Id. at 463-64, 510 S.E.2d at 425.Â  We find the exceptional circumstance 
  carefully carved out by the Johnston court is not present here.Â  Appellant 
  has already served the duration of her sentence; therefore, she does not face 
  the threat of continuing incarceration beyond the legal sentence.Â  Johnston 
  does not control.Â  
We find none of these exceptions to the general rule requiring issue 
  preservation applicable.Â  Having written to the point of expiation, we come 
  to the ineluctable conclusion that we are constrained by the preservation barrier.Â  
  Appellant will be forced to seek redress through the avenue of post-conviction 
  relief.Â  See Toal, Vafai, and Muckenfuss, Appellate Practice in South 
  Carolina at 62 (2d ed. 2002) (â€œIn criminal cases, although the failure of 
  an attorney to preserve an issue at trial will preclude appellate review of 
  that issue, it may nonetheless be a ground in a civil action for post-conviction 
  relief as a claim of ineffective assistance of counsel.â€) (citing Fossick 
  v. State, 317 S.C. 375, 453 S.E.2d 899 (1995)).
CONCLUSION
Regrettably, Appellant has suffered a violation of her right to a 
  jury trial in this case.Â  However, because she failed to raise an objection 
  at trial, we are compelled to let the unconstitutional sentence stand.Â  Accordingly, 
  the decision of the family court is
 AFFIRMED.
 BEATTY and SHORT, JJ., concur.

 
   [1]  
    We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

title: Jones v. Daley
description: In this civil action, the court reviews a special referee's finding that a property owner failed to establish a prescriptive easement for ingress and egress over a private road owned by an abutting property owner.
text:
Jones v. Daley, 13014


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Brenda Jones, Appellant,
v.
Lake W. Daley, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Jasper County
Stephen Bennett, Special Referee

Opinion No. 3951
Heard January 11, 2005 â€“ Filed February 
  22, 2005

REVERSED AND REMANDED


  
    
      
David S. Mathews, of Ridgeland, for Appellant.
R. Thayer Rivers, of Ridgeland, for Respondent.
      
    
  

 WILLIAMS, J.:Â  Brenda Jones appeals a special refereeâ€™s decision 
  that her use of Lake Daleyâ€™s property for ingress and egress to her own property 
  did not create an easement by prescription.Â  We reverse and remand.
FACTS
In 1939, Thomas Washington acquired title to fifty acres of property 
  in Jasper County.Â  This property was divided and sold to unrelated parties in 
  1963, except for a five-acre parcel Thomas gave to his daughter, Jamie Washington.Â  
  Ms. Washington granted her niece, Brenda Jones, a one-half interest in this 
  parcel in 1982.Â  In 1993, Jones was granted the remaining half interest, giving 
  her full title to the five-acre property (â€œthe Jones Parcelâ€).Â  Â Â 
Throughout the Washington familyâ€™s ownership of the Jones Parcel 
  and the larger fifty-acre tract, the only access to the property was by use 
  of a trail that followed the northern and eastern boundary of a two hundred 
  acre parcel (â€œthe Daley Parcelâ€) situated between it and the nearest public 
  road.Â  This trail, the use of which is at issue in this case, followed the Daley 
  Parcelâ€™s outer borders, but was situated entirely within the parcelâ€™s boundaries.Â  
  Union Camp owned the Daley Parcel until 1987, when it was sold to Delta Plantation.Â  
  In the late 1990s, Lake Daley purchased the two hundred acres from Delta Plantation.
Jonesâ€™s three uncles, who worked the Jones Parcel with their father, 
  original owner Thomas Washington, all testified the family actively farmed the 
  property from at least the early 1950s until 1959.Â  At some point in the early 
  1950s, Union Camp plowed the preexisting access trail for the purpose of creating 
  a firebreak.Â  Following Union Campâ€™s plowing, the Washingtons worked the plowed 
  path with shovels, leveling out the newly cleared trail to make the path more 
  suitable for ingress and egress to their property.Â  Union Camp periodically 
  plowed the firebreak, and each time the Washingtons reworked the trail to smooth 
  it down for better travel.Â  The Washingtons never requested permission to use 
  the trail because they believed, since the trail was the only access to their 
  property, they had a valid legal right to maintain and use it for ingress and 
  egress.Â  Union Camp, the Daley Parcelâ€™s owner for most of the time period at 
  issue, was aware of the Washingtonsâ€™ use and maintenance of the trail and fully 
  condoned it for over thirty-five years.Â  Â Â 
Because the Washingtons ceased farming the Jones Parcel around 
  1959, their use of the trail became less frequent in the decades that followed.Â  
  They did, however, continue to periodically visit the property and maintain 
  the trail following Union Campâ€™s plowing.Â  A nearby resident since the 1960s 
  testified that the trailâ€™s use to reach â€œburiedâ€ property was common community 
  knowledge.Â  Jones, age 46, testified the trail was used by her family to access 
  the parcel â€œas far back as [she] remembered,â€ and she specifically recalls using 
  the access herself since the 70s or 80s.Â  Because Jones is not a South Carolina 
  resident, however, her visits to the property, though many, were sporadic.Â Â  

In the mid-1990s, Delta Plantation, then owner of the Daley Parcel, 
  decided to close a road used by several other â€œburiedâ€ landowners that crossed 
  directly over the two hundred acre property.Â  To satisfy landowners who possessed 
  recorded easements over the closed road, the access trail used by the Washington 
  family was expanded into a full-sized road.Â  An employee for Delta Plantation, 
  who worked on the trail expansion, testified as to the state of the trail when 
  they decided to build the new road.Â  He stated he had maintained and expanded 
  the firebreak since the beginning of his employment in 1987.Â  Nevertheless, 
  when asked if the new road was built over an existing road, he stated, â€œNo . 
  . . there was a fireline, but just barely.â€Â  He testified that by the mid-90s 
  the trail was nothing more than a â€œdeer trail.â€Â  The employee conceded, however, 
  that the path was about eight feet wide in places and would be traversable by 
  a small tractor.Â Â Â  
Following the trailâ€™s expansion into a fully accessible road, all 
  landowners with recorded easements over the closed road were granted written 
  easements over the newly created one.Â  Because Jones did not have a recorded 
  easement to use the closed road, she was not granted a written easement to use 
  the road built over her parcelâ€™s only access. 
  [1] Â  Despite a survey her uncle commissioned in 1989 of the Jones Parcel 
  which recommended a written easement be obtained from Daley, Jones maintained 
  the belief that she had a right to use the newly created road.Â Â  
In 2001, Jones attempted to haul timber from her parcel over the 
  Daley Parcelâ€™s road.Â  Daley objected to this activity.Â  In 2002, Jones brought 
  an action against Daley to declare an easement by prescription for ingress and 
  egress over the road.Â  The appointed special referee found no easement by prescription 
  was created by Jones and her predecessorsâ€™ prior use.Â  This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
Establishing the existence of an easement is a question of fact in 
  a law action.Â  Jowers v.Â  Hornsby, 292 S.C. 549, 551, 357 S.E.2d 710, 
  711 (1987); Hartley v. John Wesley United Methodist Church of Johns Island, 
  355 S.C. 145, 148, 584 S.E.2d 386, 387 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  The present matter 
  was consensually referred to a special referee.Â  Accordingly, our scope of review 
  is limited to the correction of errors of law, and we will not disturb the refereeâ€™s 
  factual findings that have some evidentiary support.Â  Townes Assocs., Ltd. 
  v. City of Greenville, 266 S.C. 81, 85-86, 221 S.E.2d 733, 775 (1976); Hartley, 
  355 S.C. at 148, 584 S.E.2d at 387.
LAW / ANALYSIS
As a preliminary matter, we address Daleyâ€™s assertions that 
  the issues Jones raises on appeal are not preserved for our review.Â  It is Daleyâ€™s 
  position that because Jones pled she â€œowns a right to use the easement of ingress 
  and egress by prescription for continuous open hostile and adverse possession,â€ 
  she may not now assert a prescriptive easement under a claim of right on appeal.Â  
  We disagree.
â€œIt is well-settled that an issue cannot be raised for the first 
  time on appeal, but must have been raised to and ruled upon by the trial court 
  to be preserved for appellate review.â€ Â Staubes v. City of Folly Beach, 
  339 S.C. 406, 412, 529 S.E.2d 543, 546 (2000).Â  In the present case, the special 
  referee opened trial by stating to the parties and their lawyers there would 
  not be opening or closing arguments in the case.Â  Instead, the referee stated 
  he would give both parties â€œten days to submit me a letter in the way of a closing 
  argument summarizing what they think that their witnesses said and what their 
  position is as to what the ruling . . . that I make should be.â€Â  Jones, unlike 
  Daley, availed herself of this opportunity, clearly and cogently raising Jonesâ€™ 
  satisfaction of the claim of right element to establishing the easement by prescription.Â  
  The special referee, after ten months of consideration, addressed the claim 
  of right issue in his final order, but dismissed Jonesâ€™s arguments, finding 
  no easement was established.Â  Because these issues were raised to and ruled 
  upon by the special referee, we conclude they are preserved for our review.Â  
  Having addressed the issuesâ€™ preservation for appellate review, we move now 
  to the merits of the refereeâ€™s legal conclusions.
I. The Requisite Elements of Establishing a Prescriptive Easement
Jones argues the referee erred in concluding a prescriptive easement 
  can only be established by use that is both adverse and under a claim 
  of right.Â  We agree.
Relying on the case of Nelums v. Cousins, 304 S.C. 306, 308, 
  403 S.E.2d 681, 682 (Ct. App. 1991), the referee incorrectly stated the elements 
  of establishing a prescriptive easement as twenty years of use which is â€œadverse, 
  exclusive, continuous, and uninterrupted and occurred under claim of right and 
  with the knowledge or acquiescence of [the] owner of [the] servient estate or 
  predecessors in title.â€Â  Applying these elements, he concluded Jones failed 
  to establish an easement because â€œthere is no exclusive use of the premises 
  nor was the use by the Plaintiffâ€™s predecessors in title hostile or adverse 
  to that of the owner of the property in question.â€Â  
Since Nelums, South Carolina courts have simplified the elements 
  of establishing a prescriptive easement.Â  In order to establish an easement 
  by prescription, a party must only show: (1) the continued and uninterrupted 
  use or enjoyment of a right for a full period of twenty years; (2) the identity 
  of the thing enjoyed; and (3) that the use or enjoyment was adverse or 
  under a claim of right.Â  Horry County v. Lachur, 315 S.C. 364, 367, 434 
  S.E.2d 259, 261 (1993); Loftis v. South Carolina Elec. & Gas, 361 
  S.C. 434, 604 S.E.2d 714, 716 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  The source of the refereeâ€™s 
  understandable confusion on this matter was discussed and resolved in this courtâ€™s 
  case of Revis v. Barrett, 321 S.C. 206, 209 n.1, 467 S.E.2d 460, 462 
  n. 1 (Ct. App. 1996).Â  To establish an easement by prescription, one need only 
  establish either a justifiable claim of right or adverse and hostile 
  use.Â  Id.
In the present case, there is an abundance of testimony in the record 
  reflecting Jones and her predecessorâ€™s claim of right to the easement.Â  Jones 
  testified she believed she had a right to use the access because her family 
  had used it to get to and from the parcel for â€œas long as she can remember.â€ 
  All three of her uncles testified they openly asserted their perceived right 
  to use the pre-existing path with the full knowledge and acquiescence of Union 
  Camp, owner of the Daley parcel for over thirty-five years.Â  We find Jones adequately 
  demonstrated a substantial belief that she had the right to use the property 
  in a manner consistent with the alleged easement, originating from her familyâ€™s 
  prior use of the access.Â  See Loftis, 361 S.C. at __, 604 S.E.2d 
  at 717; Hartley, 355 S.C. at 151, 584 S.E.2d at 389 (â€œ[I]n order for 
  a party to earn a prescriptive easement under claim of right he must demonstrate 
  a substantial belief that he had the right to use the parcel or road based upon 
  the totality of circumstances surrounding his use.â€); Revis, 321 S.C. 
  atÂ  209-210, 467 S.E.2d at 462 (finding a prescriptive easement flowed from 
  a partyâ€™s claim of right when she was justifiably under the impression she had 
  a right to use the road).Â  Considering only the undisputed facts presented to 
  the special referee, Jones satisfied the third element of establishing a prescriptive 
  easement. 
Similarly, the referee erred in basing his decision so largely on 
  the fact that, because the Daley Parcel owners also used the trail as a firebreak, 
  Jonesâ€™s use was not exclusive.Â  As reflected in the enumerated elements above, 
  there is no requirement of exclusivity of use to establish a prescriptive easement.Â  
  An easement is the legal assertion that one has a valid right to share in the 
  use of anotherâ€™s property for a specific purpose.Â  See 25 Am. Jur. 2d 
  Easements and Licenses Â§ 1 (1996).Â  By the very nature of easements, 
  requiring that oneâ€™s use be truly exclusive to establish a prescriptive easement 
  would essentially render it impossible to establish.Â  Accordingly, even when 
  our courts have applied a requirement of exclusivity, it has been interpreted 
  narrowly as merely the requirement that oneâ€™s claim be asserted independently 
  of other users.Â  See Nelums, 304 S.C. at 308, 403 S.E.2d at 682.Â  
  Again, the refereeâ€™s confusion on this matter is understandable considering 
  the language employed by this court in the second section of Nelums and 
  the subtle, yet crucial, differences between establishing a prescriptive easement 
  and establishing ownership through adverse possession.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 
II. Continued and Uninterrupted Use
As stated in the previous section, the primary foundation of the 
  refereeâ€™s decision was an erroneous application of South Carolina law.Â  The 
  referee continued, however, to state that Jonesâ€™s use â€œdoes not appear to have 
  been continuous and uninterrupted.â€Â  It is undisputed that since Union Campâ€™s 
  acquiescence to the Washingtonsâ€™ use, no overt actions were taken by the owners 
  of the Daley Parcel to prevent use of the right of way prior to the actions 
  that gave rise to this action.Â  Jonesâ€™s use, therefore, has satisfied the â€œuninterruptedâ€ 
  requirement.Â  We are left, however, with the vague finding that the use of Jones 
  and her predecessors â€œdoes not appear to have been . . . continued.â€Â  The refereeâ€™s 
  firm decision to deny the easementâ€™s establishment on the ground of exclusivity 
  left this element largely unexplored.
As the special referee is the ultimate finder of fact in this action, 
  we remand the case for more specific findings on the issue of continued use.Â  
  We note, however, that under long established principles of South Carolina law, 
  once a right of way by prescription has been established by twenty years of 
  continuous use, a later diminishment in the frequency of that use does not necessarily 
  nullify the established right by prescription.Â  Cuthbert v. Lawton, 3 
  McCord 194, 14 S.C.L. 194 (Ct. App. 1825).Â  Furthermore, in order to satisfy 
  the continual use requirement, the use must only be of a reasonable frequency 
  as determined from the nature and needs of the claimant.Â  See 25 Am. 
  Jur. 2d Easements and Licenses Â§ 68 (1996) (â€œ[The element of continued 
  use] does not require the use thereof every day for the statutory period or 
  even on a weekly or monthly basis; but simply the exercise of the right more 
  or less frequently according to the nature of the use and the needs of the claimant.â€).
For the foregoing reasons, the special refereeâ€™s decision is
 REVERSED AND REMANDED.
 HEARN, C.J., and GOOLSBY, J., concur.

 
   [1]  The road closed by Delta Plantation in the mid-1990s 
    did not connect to the Jones Parcel.Â

title: State v. Miller
description: Appellant, who was fourteen years old at the time he was charged with the murder of his father, argues the circuit court was without jurisdiction to accept his guilty pleas to voluntary manslaughter and possession of a weapon during the commission of a violent crime because the family court erroneously waived jurisdiction.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
The State, Respondent,
v.
Kristopher M. Miller, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Anderson County
Barry W. Knobel, Family Court Judge
J.C. Nicholson, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 3952
Submitted January 1, 2005 â€“ Filed February 28, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Assistant Appellate Defender 
  Aileen P. Clare, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry 
  D. McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy 
  Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Assistant Attorney General Deborah R.J. 
  Shupe, all of Columbia; and Solicitor Druanne Dykes White, of Anderson, for 
  Respondent.
      
    
  

BEATTY, J.:Â  Kristopher Miller was fourteen years old at the time he 
  was charged with the murder of his father.Â  On appeal, he argues the circuit 
  court was without jurisdiction to accept his guilty pleas to voluntary manslaughter 
  and possession of a weapon during the commission of a violent crime because 
  the family court erroneously waived jurisdiction.Â  We affirm. 
  [1]   
FACTS
On January 2, 2001, Miller shot his father, Steve Miller, nine 
  times.Â  Miller then dragged his fatherâ€™s body into the bedroom, covered 
  it with blankets, and locked the bedroom door.Â  Unable to clean the blood in 
  the living room, Miller placed a blanket over the bloodstains.Â  Shortly thereafter, 
  Miller called his paternal grandfather, Dr. Lee Miller, and step-grandmother, 
  Joann Bock, and expressed concern that his father had left the home with someone.Â  
  He told them that he was frightened and did not want to be alone.Â  Miller left 
  a note stating that he had gone to his grandfatherâ€™s home.Â  When his grandfather 
  arrived, Miller was standing in the yard and would not let him enter the home.Â  
  According to Bock, Miller appeared â€œvery, very normal.â€
At his grandfatherâ€™s home, Miller played computer games while 
  Bock prepared dinner.Â  Before eating, Miller asked for a nailbrush so that he 
  could scrub his nails.Â  Some time during the evening, Miller called his fatherâ€™s 
  home and left a message on the answering machine.Â  In the message, Miller informed 
  his father of where he was that evening and then left his grandfatherâ€™s telephone 
  number.
Because several hours passed without hearing from his son, Dr. Miller 
  became concerned and called the South Carolina Highway Department as well as 
  several local hospitals to determine whether his son had been in an accident.Â  
  When his investigation failed to reveal any information, he filed a missing 
  personâ€™s report with the Pendleton Police Department.Â  Around 10:30 p.m., officers 
  arrived to start an initial report.
The next day, Miller, his grandfather, and Bock went to Millerâ€™s 
  home.Â  During the drive, Miller commented, â€œI just hope Dadâ€™s okay.â€Â  When they 
  entered the home, they found a blanket covered with bloodstains on the living 
  room carpet.Â  Dr. Miller followed the bloodstains down the hall to his sonâ€™s 
  locked bedroom.Â  After knocking on the door and not receiving any answer, they 
  then called 911.
Deputy Cris Vaughn was dispatched to the Miller residence. Â When 
  Vaughn kicked open the bedroom door, he discovered Steve Millerâ€™s body under 
  several blankets.Â  Investigator Rusty Garrett arrived at the home shortly after 
  Vaughn.Â  Garrett questioned Miller about the last time he saw his father 
  alive.Â  Miller responded that his father had sent him to his room around 2:15 
  p.m. the previous day when he played with his fatherâ€™s computer without first 
  asking permission.Â  Miller then told Garrett that he called his grandfather 
  after his father left the home with an unidentified male.Â  After Garrett 
  tested Millerâ€™s hands for gunshot residue, Miller told Garrett that his father 
  had raped him and that he could not take it anymore.Â  
Investigator Garrett then transported Miller to the law enforcement 
  center.Â  Miller gave a statement after being advised of his Miranda rights.Â  
  In the statement, Miller claimed that his father had sexually abused him since 
  he was ten years old.Â  Miller stated the abuse began again when he returned 
  to his fatherâ€™s home after living with his aunt and uncle from approximately 
  January 1999 until August 2000.Â  Miller further stated that he shot his 
  father when his father attempted to abuse him.Â  In an addendum to the 
  statement, Miller explained how he shot his father and identified the type of 
  weapon that he used.
After a sexual assault examination revealed no physical signs of 
  abuse, Miller gave a second statement in which he admitted that his father had 
  never sexually abused him.Â  He also claimed that he was playing with 
  the gun under his jacket when it accidentally discharged.Â  In a final statement, 
  Miller again admitted that he had lied about being sexually abused.Â  He also 
  stated that the gun went off accidentally but he panicked and kept pulling the 
  trigger.Â  He added that he retrieved a second gun from under his fatherâ€™s pillow 
  and proceeded to fire at his father until the gun was empty. 
On January 4, 2001, the State filed a juvenile petition charging 
  Miller with murder.Â  Pursuant to section 20-7-7605 
  [2]  of the South Carolina Code of Laws, the State moved to transfer jurisdiction 
  to the circuit court.Â  The family court judge heard two days of testimony, which 
  included:Â  (1) details regarding the investigation of the murder; (2) forensic 
  evidence of the crime scene; (3) Millerâ€™s family history; (4) Millerâ€™s academic 
  performance; (5) Millerâ€™s mental and emotional state; (6) Millerâ€™s adjustment 
  to the DJJ environment; and (7) the differences between a commitment to DJJ 
  and the adult prison system.Â  
Both sides offered a significant amount of testimony regarding Millerâ€™s mental 
  and emotional state before and after the incident.Â  Dr. Craig Williams, who 
  evaluated Miller for the purposes of the waiver hearing, stated that Miller 
  had an above average intelligence with an IQ of 113.Â  Dr. Williams testified 
  Miller was immature for his age, had poor interpersonal skills, and did not 
  like to be held accountable for his actions.Â  His evaluation also revealed that 
  Miller exhibited depressive symptoms.Â  He characterized Millerâ€™s ability to 
  engage in normal activities after the shooting as that of a â€œvery bazaar [sic], 
  confused individual.â€Â  In terms of Millerâ€™s remorse for shooting his father, 
  Dr. Williams testified that Miller â€œwas actually more focused on himself at 
  the time about his, his life.â€Â  As to Millerâ€™s family history, Dr. Williams 
  testified that Miller informed him that his biological mother had abandoned 
  him when he was a year old, his father was verbally and physically abusive, 
  and his father abused alcohol.Â  Dr. Williams acknowledged that Miller was taken 
  into the custody of DSS for a period of time.Â  Dr. Williams felt that Miller 
  could benefit from the highly structured environment in DJJ and the individual 
  and group counseling.Â  Based on his evaluation, Dr. Williams believed that Miller 
  was functioning more as a child as opposed to an adult and, as a result, should 
  be tried as a juvenile.Â  However, he admitted that if Miller were tried as an 
  adult he would still receive the same treatment offered to juveniles.
Dr. Julian Sharman, a clinical psychologist with DJJ, testified that 
  Miller had adapted and done â€œvery wellâ€ living in the â€œspecial needs wingâ€ at 
  DJJ.Â  He also felt that Miller had gained social maturity and that there was 
  a change in his depressive symptoms.Â  He believed that Miller would benefit 
  from the treatment available at DJJ.Â  Based on his assessment, Dr. Sharman concluded 
  that Miller should be tried as a juvenile.Â  He acknowledged that if Miller 
  were tried as an adult he would remain for a period of time in the juvenile 
  system and would for the most part receive the same services offered in the 
  juvenile system.Â  He noted that if Miller were tried as an adult, he would likely 
  be housed in a secure facility, as opposed to an â€œopen campus,â€ and as a result 
  would not have â€œquite as many services.â€ 
Dr. Elin Berg, a forensic psychiatrist, evaluated Miller at the request 
  of the defense.Â  She diagnosed Miller as having a major depressive disorder, 
  post-traumatic stress disorder, and a reading disorder.Â  She felt Miller did 
  not exhibit psychotic behavior and there was no evidence of an anti-social personality 
  disorder.Â  She assessed Miller as ten years old in terms of his maturity level.Â  
  Dr. Berg also believed that Miller was amenable to rehabilitation and could 
  receive individual and group therapy at DJJ.Â  Based on her evaluations, Dr. 
  Berg recommended that Miller be tried as a juvenile.
After the hearing, the family court judge ordered Millerâ€™s case to 
  be transferred to circuit court.Â  In his order, the judge outlined in 
  detail the testimony of each witness as well as the substance of significant 
  exhibits, which included a mental competency evaluation.Â  Based on the evidence, 
  the judge concluded, â€œit is unlikely this Juvenile could be successfully rehabilitated 
  by, or within, the juvenile system, and it is in the best interests of the Juvenile 
  and the community to transfer jurisdiction to the Court of General Sessions.â€Â  

On January 15, 2002, an Anderson County grand jury indicted Miller for murder 
  and possession of a firearm during the commission of a violent crime.Â  Approximately 
  a week later, Miller pled guilty to voluntary manslaughter and the related weapon 
  charge.Â  The circuit court sentenced Miller to thirty years imprisonment, suspended 
  upon the service of twenty years and five years probation.Â  The court 
  sentenced Miller to a concurrent, five-year term of imprisonment for the weapon 
  charge.
Miller appeals the family court judgeâ€™s 
  order transferring jurisdiction to the circuit court.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The appellate court will affirm a transfer order unless the family 
  court has abused its discretion.Â  State v. Avery, 333 S.C. 284, 292, 
  509 S.E.2d 476, 481 (1998).Â  â€œThe term â€˜abuse of discretionâ€™ has no opprobrious 
  implication and may be found if the conclusions reached by the lower court are 
  without reasonable factual support.â€Â  State v. Corey D., 339 S.C. 107, 
  118, 529 S.E.2d 20, 26 (2000); Engle v. Engle, 343 S.C. 444, 449-50, 
  539 S.E.2d 712, 714 (Ct. App. 2000) (stating an abuse of discretion occurs when 
  the court is controlled by an error of law or where the order, based upon the 
  findings of fact, is without evidentiary support).Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 
DISCUSSION
Miller argues the circuit court lacked jurisdiction to accept his 
  guilty pleas because the family court erroneously waived jurisdiction.Â  Specifically, 
  Miller contends the family court judgeâ€™s factual conclusions are without evidentiary 
  support.Â  We disagree.
In reaching the decision to waive jurisdiction to the circuit court, 
  the family court judge relied on the criteria established in Kent v. United 
  States, 383 U.S. 541 (1966), [3] 
   which have been â€œimplicitly approved as appropriate criteria.â€Â  Corey 
  D., 339 S.C. at 118, 529 S.E.2d at 26.Â  In assessing whether the family 
  court judge abused his discretion, â€œwe consider the Kent factors and 
  emphasize that the serious nature of the offense is a major factor in the transfer 
  decision.â€Â  Id.
As will be discussed, we find the judge sufficiently outlined the 
  factual findings upon which he based his decision and those facts are supported 
  by the testimony and evidence presented at the transfer hearing.Â  
Under the first factor, the judge found that there was â€œno more serious 
  offense to the communityâ€ than murder and â€œthat if â€˜protection to the communityâ€™ 
  was the sole criteria, there would be no question that waiver to the Court of 
  General Sessions would be necessary.â€Â  In making this determination, the judge 
  struggled with the testimony that Miller had no history of criminal behavior 
  and the experts indicated that Miller could be rehabilitated within the juvenile 
  justice system.Â  The judge contrasted this testimony with the fact that:Â  Miller 
  possessed above average intelligence; he gave multiple differing accounts of 
  the incident; and he attempted to conceal the crime and create an alibi.
Miller concedes that the offense of murder is serious.Â  There is 
  also evidence supporting the judgeâ€™s conclusion regarding the protection of 
  the community.Â  Although the psychological experts testified that Miller could 
  be rehabilitated, they also acknowledged that there was no guarantee that Miller 
  would not commit another violent crime.Â  Several of Millerâ€™s own family members 
  testified that they were afraid of him.Â  Jeanette and Mark Henry, Millerâ€™s paternal 
  aunt and uncle, with whom he stayed for approximately a year and a half preceding 
  the shooting, testified that Miller was forced out of their home because he 
  was suspended from school for bringing a knife and he wrote a note threatening 
  to kill their family.Â  Moreover, the record reflects that Miller did 
  not appear to be remorseful after shooting his father.Â  Dr. Williams specifically 
  testified that Miller â€œwas actually more focused on himself at the time about 
  his, his life.â€Â  In his statement, Miller admitted that:Â  he attempted to conceal 
  the shooting by cleaning the living room; he hid one of the weapons at his grandfatherâ€™s 
  home; and he wrote a note and left a voicemail message to explain his whereabouts.Â  
  Bock also testified that Miller appeared normal after the incident.Â  Investigator 
  Garrett testified that Miller changed his statement several times and ultimately 
  admitted that his father did not sexually abuse him, which was the reason Miller 
  initially gave as prompting the shooting.Â Â  Â Â 
Regarding the second factor, the judge found the evidence established 
  that the â€œcrime was committed in an aggressive, violent and wilful manner; and 
  that premeditation cannot be excluded from the scenario or sequence of events 
  occurring on January 2, 2001.â€Â  The testimony of the investigating officers 
  and the forensic evidence supports the judgeâ€™s conclusion.Â  Dr. Woodard, the 
  forensic pathologist, testified that the victim had nine gunshot wounds, which 
  included three to the front of the body, one to the right side, three to the 
  back, and two to the left side of the head.Â  He further testified the pattern 
  of the wounds was consistent with the victim crawling on the ground while being 
  shot.Â  Investigator Mike Mitchell testified the crime scene evidence indicated 
  that the victim was lying on the floor when he was shot in the head.Â  He further 
  explained the evidence indicated that the shooter was â€œtrackingâ€ the victim.Â  
  Dorothy Filiatreault, a SLED forensic chemist, testified the victim was shot 
  a few times at close range.Â  Miller also admitted, and the forensic evidence 
  corroborated, that he shot his father using two separate weapons.Â  Additionally, 
  one could infer premeditation from Millerâ€™s act of shooting the weapon through 
  his jacket.
With respect to the third, fourth and fifth factors, there is no 
  dispute that evidence supports the judgeâ€™s findings.Â  Without question, 
  the offense of murder was committed against a person.Â  Moreover, Miller concedes 
  that the evidence â€œmight sustain an indictment for murder.â€Â  Miller also 
  admits that the fifth factor is inapplicable to his case given there were no 
  co-defendants involved in the shooting.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 
In terms of the sixth factor, the judge indicated that this factor 
  â€œcreated the greatest dilemmaâ€ apparently because of the conflicting evidence 
  presented by the defense and the State.Â  The judge outlined this evidence and 
  ultimately concluded, â€œ[t]he sheer violence of the murder, and the Juvenileâ€™s 
  elaborate efforts to create an alibi and/or conceal evidence, . . . show a degree 
  of intellect and sophistication even beyond the age of this Juvenile.â€Â Â  

As evidenced by the judgeâ€™s order, it is clear that he considered all aspects 
  of Millerâ€™s life in reaching this conclusion.Â  Although, as the judge recognized, 
  there was evidence that Miller had a difficult home life, he was assessed as 
  immature for his age, and he was a loner, there was also evidence weighing in 
  favor of transferring jurisdiction to the circuit court.Â  Millerâ€™s allegations 
  of abuse were never substantiated other than for limited testimony that Millerâ€™s 
  father had been on occasion physically and verbally abusive and the inference 
  from Millerâ€™s limited stay in the custody of DSS four years prior to the incident.Â  
  A physical examination of Miller after the shooting did not reveal any evidence 
  of sexual abuse.Â  After the examination, Miller in fact admitted that he had 
  lied about the sexual abuse.Â  Moreover, Miller spent time away from his father 
  when he lived with other relatives.Â  By all accounts, Miller had a good relationship 
  with his paternal grandfather and step-grandmother.Â  Millerâ€™s maternal grandmother, 
  Carol Click, also testified that Miller spent summers with her family.Â  Miller 
  also lived for approximately a year and a half with his paternal aunt and uncle, 
  Jeanette and Mark Henry, until they felt he was a threat to their family.Â  Furthermore, 
  even though Drs. Williams, Sharman, and Berg diagnosed Miller with depression 
  and an anxiety disorder, they found no evidence for which to classify Miller 
  as having a definitive anti-social disorder.Â  
As to the seventh factor, there is no evidence that Miller had any 
  prior criminal record or adjudicative history. 
Concerning the final factor, the judge found that â€œif this 
  Juvenile was to remain within the jurisdiction of the Family Court and be adjudicated 
  delinquent and sentenced as required by law, he could not be successfully 
  rehabilitated by any program, or by any combination of programs, presently offered 
  by this Stateâ€™s juvenile system.â€Â  As a result, the judge believed â€œthat after 
  the Juvenile completed his period of juvenile detention, there would remain 
  a constant risk to the community that certain stressors placed on this Juvenile, 
  even as he entered adulthood, might result in his sudden, violent response to, 
  or against, the cause of the stress.â€Â  Although there is evidence to 
  support the judgeâ€™s implicit finding that Miller would only serve a limited 
  amount of time in DJJ if tried as a juvenile, we find there is no evidence to 
  support his conclusion that Miller could not be successfully rehabilitated by 
  any program offered in the juvenile system.Â  All of the psychological experts 
  as well as Marlene McClain, a former member of the juvenile parole board, recognized 
  that if Miller were tried as a juvenile he may only spend thirty-six to forty-four 
  months at DJJ.Â  However, they all believed that Miller could benefit from treatment 
  that he would receive at DJJ.Â  Dr. Berg specifically testified that she believed 
  Miller was â€œamenable to rehabilitation.â€Â  Even Dr. Williams, who indicated that 
  Miller may be difficult to rehabilitate, ultimately concluded that â€œ[g]iven 
  [Millerâ€™s] level of cognitive ability, with tutoring, therapeutic support, and 
  a structured environment, he might perform more adequately at school and might 
  be able to develop vocational skills.â€Â  Therefore, we find the judge erred in 
  reaching his conclusion regarding the eighth Kent factor.
CONCLUSION
We find there is evidence to support the family court judgeâ€™s ruling 
  regarding all of the Kent factors with the exception of factor eight, 
  which involves Millerâ€™s potential for rehabilitation within the juvenile system.Â  
  Because, however, there is evidence in the record to support the family court 
  judgeâ€™s overall decision to waive jurisdiction over Miller to the circuit court, 
  we hold he did not abuse his discretion.Â  Therefore, the circuit court had jurisdiction 
  to accept Millerâ€™s guilty pleas.Â  Accordingly, Millerâ€™s convictions and sentences 
  are
 AFFIRMED. 
HUFF and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.

 
   [1]  Because oral argument would not aid the court 
    in resolving the issues on appeal, we decide this case without oral argument 
    pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

 
   [2] Â  Section 20-7-7605 provides in pertinent part:
  
  (5) If a child fourteen or fifteen years of age is charged with 
    an offense which, if committed by an adult, would be a Class A, B, C, or D 
    felony as defined in Section 16-1-20 or a felony which provides for a maximum 
    term of imprisonment of fifteen years or more, the court, after full investigation 
    and hearing, may determine it contrary to the best interest of the child or 
    of the public to retain jurisdiction.Â  The court, acting as committing magistrate, 
    may bind over the child for proper criminal proceedings to a court which would 
    have trial jurisdiction of the offenses if committed by an adult.
  
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-7605(5) (Supp. 2004).Â  

 
   [3] Â Â  In approving these factors, our Supreme Court 
    has stated:Â  
  
  In Kent, the United States Supreme Court noted the following 
    criteria for determining whether jurisdiction should be waived under the District 
    of Columbia Juvenile Court Act:
    
  1. The seriousness of the alleged offense to the community and 
    whether the protection of the community requires waiver.Â  
  2. Whether the alleged offense was committed in an aggressive, 
    violent, premeditated, or willful manner.Â  
  3. Whether the alleged offense was against persons or against 
    property, greater weight being given to offenses against persons especially 
    if injury resulted.Â  
  4. The prosecutive merit of the complaint, i.e., whether there 
    is evidence upon which a Grand Jury may be expected to return an indictment 
    . . . .
  5. The desirability of trial and disposition of the entire offense 
    in one court when the juvenileâ€™s associates in the alleged offense are adults 
    who will be charged with a crime . . . .
  6. The sophistication and maturity of the juvenile as determined 
    by consideration of his home, environmental situation, emotional attitude 
    and pattern of living.Â  
  7. The record and previous [criminal or adjudicative] history 
    of the juvenile . . . .
  8.Â  The prospects for adequate protection of the public 
    and the likelihood of reasonable rehabilitation of the juvenile (if he is 
    found to have committed the alleged offense) by the use of procedures, services 
    and facilities currently available to the Juvenile Court.Â  
    
  
  Corey D., 339 S.C. at 116 n.4, 529 S.E.2d at 
    25 n.4 (citing Kent, 383 U.S. at 566-67).
